reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't understand.

These devs started this game off as a simple top-down dinosaur shooter.

And it got a working 3rd person mode less than six months later.

And it's getting a full open-world in a few months.

And within a year it's supposed to get a fully explorable galaxy.

And you can get founder's access to said game for just a dollar.

And yet EA's Battlefront costs $60+ and look what that nets you.

EDIT (5/29/16): All right so I've spent a bit more time in the game, and it's great, a really solid top-down shooter, a really solid third-person shooter, a really solid soon-to-be FPS. It just needs optimization and bug fixes that's all.

I also just want to say again how great it is that the developers are basically planning on turning this into not just one, but many games for the low price of $1. It's already a TPS & TDS, it's gonna be an FPS really soon, and they're also planning on adding mech modes, PvP modes, racing modes, campaigns that are inspired by other games (first campaign is inspired by DOOM apparently), Raids & Strikes, open world, and soooo much more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Inspiring developers working on what is sure to be a great game.
Man I love Trek. The same developers that made one of the absolute WORST games of 2012 (Orion: Dino Beatdown) are the same developers that have made an early access game that, if I were in the monetary position to do so, would support them all the way through.

These developers made fun of their own failures and came back with a highly appreciated game called Orion: Prelude. It saddens me that many people don't think of how great these developers are. They got beaten up twice, failing at a game and failing again at a Kickstarter project, but they have shown both times that they will keep trying, and when they do, the result is amazing. These guys clearly show no signs of giving up, and if you're one of devs reading this, I want you to know that there are people who look up to that as inspiration. I wish there were more people like you and your team making games for the world.

And now we have a wave-based survival game known as: [ THE ORION PROJECT ]

PROS
+You are a space man, but not a run-of-the-mill spaceman, you are a spaceman that is sent to eliminate...

+...DINOSAURS! Compsognathus, Deinonychus, Dilophosaurus, Rhamphorynchus, Allosaurus, Ankylosaurus, Triceratops, and Tyrannosaurus Rex!

+ Alien creatures! Dinos aren't the only enemies you'll encounter. Some other baddies you'll run into after the first two waves or so are alien creatures such as the Jeckyl, the Kruger, and the Namor.

+ Robotic antagonists. Every once in a while, there will be a wave where you may have to fight robot adversaries and a boss to get a bonus chest. The names (as stated by user Deligor and my personal in-game confirmation) of these robots are named Bones, a humaniod robot with a blaster, Orbs, the floating drones that fire grenades, and Grump, the large, humaniod robot boss with dual-wielding swords. Trek has not given out OFFICIAL names for the robots, and we have yet to see how they play out in the game's story/lore.

+ An above average amount of classes with unique abilities: Assault, (who has a jet pack), Support, (who can set up a bubble that heals teammates), Recon (who can turn invisible), Pyro (who gets a flamethrower), Marksman (who can use thermal vision), Rocketeer (WHO GETS A ROCKET LAUNCHER), and my personal favorite, Tech (who can place a turret)!

+ Absolutely beautiful graphics. Great textures, great lens flares/lighting, depth of field, and motion blur. This game doesn't look like early access, especially on super high" settings.

+ Fun online multiplayer. Playing with others online is SO much more fun than playing by yourself on solo. I've played several matches and everyone seems nice (helping new players out
hoursPlayed: making the online experience all the more enjoyable!\n\n+ XP and Leveling up. Enough is said there. Kill dinos
voteText: get XP
helpfulPercent: level up
votesHelpful: repeat.\n\n+ Crafting system. In both solo and multiplayer
votesTotal: when you kill dinosaurs and creatures
votesFunny: they will drop materials that you can craft into things like medkits and boosts. Some are exclusive to crafting and cannot be purchased in the shop.\n\n+ Skill tree. When you level up
commentsCount: you get one skill point to use on each of the three attributes: "character"
column17: and "miscellaneous". You need five total skill points if you want to obtain the skill you're working towards.\n\n+ Boosters and consumables. In the game

column20: which are good if you're looking to complete a skill you've been working on. Consumables
column22: can be purchased with the game's easily obtainable currency known as ION.\n\n+ Many things planned for the future! more maps
column30: flying in space to planets and visiting cities in your own STARSHIP
column34: MORE CUSTOMIZATION just to name a few. So many things are planned that I almost don't believe that these guys can finish it all in a year
column37:
I know they can and will do it.

+ Improved camera movement.


CONS
- Minor bugs and iffy animation in third person.

- They have a "play or pay" system. The game has two currencies:ION and Trek. You are either able to either play normally and earn ION or pay for Trek. The developers claim that there will be no pay wall
column38: and Trek only gets you cosmetic things such as hats
column40: etc. I am personally uncomfortable with this because of how many great games have become pay-to-win starting with the dual currencies. You could be buying hats now
column41: but you could also be buying revives and renting OP guns in the future. I've seen paid currency destroy the best of games; free or not
column42: which is why it is a concern I have with all games
column43:
especially early-access titles with a plentiful amount of potential.

Opinionated Thoughts....
I really like these developers. They seem to show no signs of giving up just because of too much negative feedback and failed projects. On a different note
column44: the fact that they added dual currencies so early in development worries me. I feel like they should have waited until the full release
column45: when it's only a dollar. (which would

column51: which actually gets you some neat-looking armor and hats (Founder's access event has ended). I have a bad feeling about it. Still
column52:
don't let it decide whether you purchase or not.

SUMMARY
All-in-all
column53: this is an early-access game that you definitely want in your library. The game is only one dollar and will continue to be a dollar even after the full launch in 2017. If you're looking for an early access title to support or just follow

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: Great game but can be boring/repetitive, wouldn't pay full price.

PROS:

+Beautiful Graphics (Pretty well optimized compared to other games, with a 970 I get 50-60fps on Max settings. Although lowering in game settings doesn't hugely impact my frames.)
+Dinosaurs (Dinosaurs are always awesome.)
+Multiple Classes
+RPG Elements (Skill Tree, Inventory/Looting System.)
+Variety of enemies (Not to huge, but there are still some unique enemies.)
+Bosses (2 I think?)
+Side objectives (Still basically a normal wave, but you have to go somewhere to kill the enemies.)
+Amazing Devs who respond to most users, frequently fix bugs and add content monthly.
+Fun with friends
+Nice, Clean Menus
+Good Music

CONS:

-Music tends to be a bit wierd from time to time (Instantly goes from calm to heavy metal.)
-Not as fun without friends
-TL:DR: Very Easy, only difficult on hard or with more friends (more friends = higher difficult I think, not too sure). Even if the harvester manages to be destroyed, you have 3 minutes before it dies and you lose, and it only takes 10 seconds to repair it (Which can be done whilst moving around). If you get downed, you have to kill a few enemies before you die, and if you do, you are instantly revived with full health. You also have infinite lives, with about a 30 seconds respawn timer, which is enough time to respawn and fix the harvester. Also, the Magnum seems to be slightly over powered with good accuracy, kills most enemies in one hit (the bigger guys take a few more), the only downside being the slow projectile speed (on a magnum?) making it fairly difficult to kill the flying enemies. Sorry for the really long point, just felt I needed to point these out.
-Most servers are American, meaning an AU player like myself would be lucky to find a server with a ping lower than 250. This also makes the gore pretty lame as there is a wierd delay when shooting the heads off. (You can't level if your not online, meaning even solo has bad ping)
-Some aspects can be confusing (HUD, inventory, crafting) but there are tooltips (Which aren't the most helpful)
-Only a few Maps
-Only 2 Gamemodes (They are very similar, one is infinite survival whilst the other is waves.)
-Although content is being added monthly, as of now, it only takes a few hours before you see most of what it has to offer.
-All bullets look like slow moving glowing balls (Not a huge con, just not very fond of the style and I dislike how all weapons have the same projectiles, just different colours and speeds.

Some extra points from recent updates and dev blogs:

-Difficulty if much harder now if you play on hard, as the newly implemented level system can make the enemies a much more difficult.

-The Developers where going to discontinue the game in a few months due to the game not as selling as well as they hoped, however the 90% off sale had funded them enough to promise a few more big updates (A 40 player hub to do quests, 2 vehicles, some maps, possibly first person and lots of tweaks to the gameplay)

-Whoever purchasing the game before the game is discontinued and is reduced to $1, recieves all future guardians for free and 20,000 in game credits to buy vanity items (Like Orion: Prelude), those who purchase the game after it is reduced to $1 will have to pay $10 to any extra Guardians and will not recieve the credits.

Overall: 8/10, Needs some balancing and fixing. The Devs are promising monthly content updates (New Map, New Character etc.)
Thanks for reading, any feedback is appreciated.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access done right!
+ Lots of updates with regular fixes
+ Transparency from the devs
+Added content free (for now, anyways)
+ A realistic roadmap
+ Devs are dreaming BIG about this game.


**EDIT APR 23 - Version 1.4**

So this morning I'm trying out the new Rocketeer Class, and I go back into the lobby after the round to find the DEVELOPER online answering questions and taking oppinions and feedback. I had made a suggestion in the forum, so I asked about it, and he confirmed that it will be in the next update with some other ideas the community had offered.

Aside from this game being oddly fun, I love that there's a group of people working on this game to make it work how we want, while pushing their own ideas further.

My only critique from last time was that I wanted to jump. Now I can jump, but it's bound to the same key as roll. I'm sure it will be fixed, but I lol'd when I was trying to figure out how to roll again.

It's not a perfect game by any means, but I still haven't touched my growing backlog of AAA games since getting into Guardians


**Original Review - Version 1.3**

I was given this game by a friend for a gaming event, and while I wasn't hooked right away, I kept coming back. Now I'm hooked. I've got 6 AAA games waiting to be played, but I'm having a LOT OF FUN playing Guardians.

There are issues with the game, but they're constantly being fixed, so there's not really any point listing them. Other than lack of jumping. I get why, since the game can be played top down, but it's hard to just not jump.

I'll probably update this later too...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Originally I bought this game when it was $20 USD and I refunded it because at the time it was hard to justify that price tag for what the current state of the game is.
I thought (and still do) think it is a good game, but again for $20 there's a lot of good and even great games out there that you could get for that price and well below.

But at $2 a pop? Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me?
I bought one copy for myself and five other copies to gift to my friends, at $2 a copy this game is worth it on every level.
For $2 this is a steal, I almost feel bad for getting this game for this price because on a graphical level it's beautiful, it runs moderately well and it's a fun game with some new ideas.
The music is absolutely kick ♥♥♥, at the current price point at this time ($2) this is robbery and I recommend this game to anyone at that price point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in Early Access, This game has all the makings of a very fun co-op game, and like ORION: Prelude before it, I trust David Prassel to deliver, come hell or high water.  There is no stopping this developer from giving the community what it pays for.  Even if he got eaten by a dinosaur, I think they would finish development, and make it good.

Edit:  Following the February Update, there has been a huge influx of new players, new content, and at $2 for the duration of the sale, you will be kicking yourself for not picking up the title while you can still get founder level content access.  This is not a title that will be abandoned in Early Access, the Dev has a solid history of delivering content, even when historically faced with financial struggle.  It's $2!  Support a quality developer, buy a copy for yourself, and 20 copies for your friend's list.  I did.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had huge fun testing this game, and later playing the current early release (1.0.1)
This is a birds eye view perspective twin stick shooter, where both mouse/keyboard and controller work very well.
You will have a blast learning to use the varied arsenal of each class and learning how to effectively take down every dinosaur and machine that crosses your path.  The main online mode challenges you to survive ten increasingly difficult waves while you protect and repair the harvester.  You will shoot, stab, throw grenades, jetpack, cloak, mini teleport and regen your way to victory.

The current waves are quicker to blast through than what you remember from Orion Prelude and the action is more constant on these smaller maps.  It took me two or three rounds to get used to the game enough to master normal mode, but I had fun doing it, and eventually challenging hard, and even ridikulous modes with friends (spoiler: you won't survive round 1 of redik with a 4-person team.

After you have played a few matches online you'll have built up a few points to spend on customising each of the three classes to your personal play-style.  This starts with simple options like do you want to move faster, while sprinting or aiming?  Or even faster recharging grenades?

Later you will get more class specific perks, but these are likely to change.  A fully levelled up recon class could share cloaking with friends, but I believe now that they just suffer less damage if hit while cloaked.

There is fun to be had playing by yourself, working your way up the ranks to beating hard mode by yourself for the first time.  However the best of the game is having fun against increasing numbers of dinos in a larger team online.
All fighting for survival and trying to keep the squad and harvester alive.

Numbers of dinos increase depending on how many players are on the server.  Best example of this was a friend bragging the he and a mate beat the game on highest redik difficulty in 2-player mode.  Then he attempted it in four-player with some n00bs (me!) and... it did not go well haha.

I highly recommend this game.  The enemies are great to fight, and you will have a blast online no matter who you are playing with.  Definitely jump on board the GoO band wagon!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You will get stabbed by a Kruger by surprise and die instantly.

You can get grand slammed out of bounds by a giraffe shaped dinosaur.

You can get 360 noscoped by a T-Rex using a boulder.

You will die to a robotic hulk wielding 2 lightsabers doing a front flip.

You can get pounced by a raptor and then proceed to be stomped by a T-Rex.

You will die to grenades while reviving a teammate.

You will be eaten by a T-Rex for dinner.

But you can use a healing gun as a weapon of mass destruction.

9/10 for an early access game

SERIOUS NOTE:

At this moment, the game is fairly buggy, and has little content. If you want to help this game grow, then buy this game now. If you want to play the game when it has a little more content(and possibly less bugs), buy it somewhere in January/Febuary.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

REVIEW UPDATED!


From what i played thus far, i am really enjoying my time spent playing this game! Also, this review will be updated more in the future when more updates roll out and improve the game.


Pros:

+It's intense

+Fatalities. Yes, you and the dinos can brutalize each other. For instance, Big-T (you know who that is) took a bite outta me, and then i cut a raptor's head off.

+ Nice soundtrack

+ It's good looking (Unreal Engine 4 <3)

+ It's optimized for the most part. Better than most Game's in Early Access.

+ The devs are active on the forums during the day, and respond to questions and feedback

+ Dinosaurs. How could one NOT love a good game about Dinosaurs?

+ You can now switch between Third Person & the usual Top-Down, Isometric view.

+ They'll be updating the game every month with a new guardian, and more content. Maybe more performance optimizations here and there as well. (They're gonna optimize the game further this next patch!)

+ This game now has a decent size playerbase!

+ Slaughter is more fun than ever now. Especially now that the game is a little more popular. They even fixed a bug where the game would suddenly end after like 2-3 waves.


Cons:

-There seem to be a small bug with the Third-Person aiming. Sometimes as you enter a game, your character will start slowly looking a certain direction. It can't be fixed in-game as far as i know, so to stop that from happening just disconnect from the game and start up a new one/rejoin the server you were in. (UPDATE: This happens when you open and close the Steam overlay)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


On that note, i still highly reccommend this game. It's fun even on solo, but co-op is where the real fun is! If you are gonna buy this game, and you like it, be sure to tell your friends about it. As stated above, it's really low on players, and this game has a LOT of potential to be The Must own Shooter". If you get it now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated as of build 1.2.1

I'm a big fan of Orion: Prelude. I initially played it when it was called Orion: Dino Horde, so I never experienced the horror that was Orion: Dino Beatdown. Guardians of Orion is a completely different game from its predecessors. Prelude was a true FPS, whereas Guardians is a top-down arcade style shooter with a wonky 3rd person option. Guardians was clearly built and balanced around the top-down camera angle, and 3rd person was thrown in as an afterthought due to popular demand.

The best way to describe the difference between Prelude and Guardians is this: Prelude is to Call of Duty's Nazi Zombies as Guardians is to CoD's Dead Ops Arcade. I hope this clarifys for everyone exactly what kind of game Guardians is.

Now, some people are going to be disappointed that Guardians isn't an FPS, but others will prefer the arcade style shooter. That's just up to your individual tastes.

EDIT: Guardians of Orion will be featuring a first-person mode in the near future. (Spring 2016)

The core gameplay or Guardians is fun after playing a few matches, but I can imagine it getting very boring and repetitive after a short while. There are currently only 5 maps, 2 game modes, and a day/night option. Considering it is still in early access, I'm sure they will gradually release new maps and game modes, but as of now that is it.

Something I really enjoy about Guardians is the addition of a skill tree and crafting system. This helps make each class (Assault, Support, Recon. Tech, Pyro) feel much more unique, as they each level up individually and have their own unique skill trees. I have no experience with the crafting system yet, however I think that it will give players an incentive to grind the somewhat limited content in order to craft super cool weapons and items.

I'm honestly a little confused and disappointed as to why they chose not to include either a campaign or a competitive versus game mode in Guardians. Most games draw success either from a compelling story mode, or an intense and addicting competitive scene. It is very difficult to retain player interest with only a co-op surivival arcade game. Perhaps those features are in the works, but if not I can't see myself spending more than 10 hours on this game, unless the crafting ends up being highly addicting!

The graphics are beautiful when you enter 3rd person mode, so again I'm a little confused as to why they chose a top-down camera angle to build the game around. I'd rather enjoy the graphics froms 3rd person, but it puts you at a massive disadvantage because you can't see flying enemies very well, and the tiny dinos are impossible to spot in the tall grass. Not to mention it is much harder to turn around in 3rd person quickly due to low sensitivity relative to top-down sensitivity.

One little teeny thing I really wish they would add is a ready up" feature. I feel the down time between rounds is too long for most rounds
date: so if they had a voting system to immediately start the next round that would really reduce frustration and boredom
recommended: because you end up doing nothing for 10 minutes out of each game (1 minute down time between rounds x 10 rounds). *This feature was added to the game as of build 1.2.1
voteText: I give Guardians a 7/10 because the core gameplay is fun
helpfulPercent: but replay value is just not there at this point in time. It is on sale right now for $2 and I HIGHLY recommend buying it. However
votesHelpful: when it returns to it's normal price of $20
votesTotal: I'd wait until they release more maps and game modes before spending that much on it."

At the moment I cannot give this game a favorable review.  I've supported Trek and Mr. Prassel in their previous attempts such as Orion: Prelude and such and even bought this game when it came out as Guardians of Orion.  The game was, at the start, littered with bugs rendering it unplayable for many people.  I stopped playing the game early on after Prassel got annoyed with some of the bug reports and basically said the problems were the users' faults and not his (that he basically wasn't going to spend time fixing the issue since it only affected a small portion of the community).  I came back months later after new updates to see if any of the issues were resolved.  Sadly, the game still has a million and one technical issues (including poor optimization for many PCs).  INSTEAD of fixing the issues, Trek and Prassel are pushing new content rather than addressing problems.  A few members of the community have even narrowed down certain problems so that any fix would be easier to spot but there has been no response from the development team whether on the forums or in email.

Technical issues can be fixed but the lack of response and childish behavior from the development team push this game into a thumbs down" for the time being.  If things change I might possibly revert that.


Edit:  Mr. Prassel's comment regarding specificity to this review shall be obliged below.  I'll try to be as concise as possible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I recieved a free copy of this game as part of a giveaway. However, I did invest money buying copies for my friends pre-price drop, so don't think I'm reviewing it with no money in.

This game is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. 100/100

This game brilliantly shines in 3rd person mode. It is truly beautiful and Unreal Engine 4 looks so good. The maps are well thought out and planned excellently. Also, I've never spoken with developers who are so involved in the community. You can see their love for gaming in the quality and care they take of this release. The developers are super dedicated and have carried over their passion from their previous game(s) to this one. The updates are regular, significant, and very welcomed.

Sure, there are a few small bugs (sometimes robots sliding like slugs on their stomachs at the ground, raptors flying into the air), but the gameplay, guardians (classes), and the inventory system fully make up for it.

This is truly an amazing game and I feel everyone should play it. I can't fit all the good things about this game in this review so here are just a couple more. The developers have left in that you're quite protected if you jetpack on top of a rock, however they've made robots that can hit you up there as well as poison pools. It doesn't seem unfair yet still keeps the integrity of the previous game in the series. It is a remarkable balance they've found.

I've played this game since it was in private access, and I must say it's one of the most addicting games I've ever played. Having switched to PC Gaming, this is my version of Destiny." The loot system seems even better and more fair than Destiny was last I'd kept up with it (aprox. April 2015). I have worked to max levelling 2 of my Guardians so far and am happily awaiting the next release to play with the Marksman Guardian and the new level cap.

I'm also very much looking forward to the strike missions (high level raids) that are planned in the future. This has become a very ambitious project and the developers seem like their going to be able to deliver with all the love they have for this game and their fans.

"Throw a better version of Destiny's loot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(I know there is a big blue banner reminding my readers that this is an early access game so take what I say seriously but with the understanding that it's still a work in progress. )

Guardians of Orion provides for some FPS arcade fun while giving the player some neat abilities to work with. I especially like it's concept as you can go from a top-down view to a first person view (which I think is a great addition). Although the game can be immersive (especially with friends), it can be redundant after a bit.

The game's structure is either a survival mode or slaughter mode. In survival mode you defend your harvester. It can defend itself but will need your help in maintaining it's health. In slaughter mode, the harvester is on the move! Unlike survival, you'll have to keep moving with the machine in order to keep it alive. If the machine becomes damaged, the player may repair it with a special weapon (that is given to the player). Any player of any class may repair the machine. All classes come with one main weapon and a side arm. On top of having basic abilities including roll, teleport, and grenade, each class has their own unique ability. There are four classes available at the moment : assault, support, tech and recon.

Assault class is my favorite as they are given jet packs as their special ability and have an automatic weapon at their disposal. Support class has a shotgun instead of an automatic rifle and can deploy a healing bubble as his specialty. The tech can deploy a machine turret as their ability and the recon can turn invisible for a time being. This last class is given an EMP grenade to tackle robot type units. The grenade function isn't extremely effective at the moment and it's physics aren't exactly right. Imagine running then throwing, there isn't an extra umph" and the trajectory feel isn't quite as right. Every class has an ability to upgrade their skill tree (this can be seen in the screenshots). Players can upgrade their melee ability or choose to be faster. There are three trees in total with usually two options to choose from. I believe adding this into the game can really make it stand out. As mentioned
date: the player can cycle through a top-down view or a first person view. I like to stick with a first person view when I'm engaging flying type units (to shoot in the air) but the overview helps when you're being swarmed by enemies. Small enemy dinosaurs
recommended:
for example are difficult to see in first person as they can mask their movements through the grass.

The enemies themselves are pretty varied (even for early access) and some enemies will have you running for your life while you're trying to shoot at them. I really like the variety and the choice of enemies. Players are able to sprint in game while crouching is not available (I couldn't imagine what you would use it for anyway). I think they did a pretty good job allocating the controls and given the player a good feel of control over their unit.

The graphics are OK at the moment. Their neither extremely good
voteText: rather in between. You'll notice anything green or some rock edges not being exactly smooth (but this is okay because there is time to touch this up)! This also won't effect your game play experience. Sounds are pretty good but I would recommend adding some sort of scream when a big enemy starts charging at you. Make the player scared and excited to play! Although sounds do not directly effect game play
helpfulPercent: they can change how the player is feeling in any moment of the game. The first Splinter Cell did it with one note being played hard on a piano
votesHelpful: I'm sure GofO can do something similar or even better.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: not a bad game. It feels like a mix between Halo
votesFunny: Turok and some defense FPS's out there. There is no campaign at the moment (I hope there is one) and multiplayer servers aren't exactly full. It will be tough finding a game. I would highly recommend getting this game on the premise that either you like it for what it is
commentsCount:
or that you'll be playing it with a friend. I really hope as well they make it so you can burn the grass as you fire through it or some sort of effects along those lines. The game sort of lacks in this department regarding effects.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review in a minute: https://youtu.be/TQ7Ouxat-bY

It’s a 4 player co-op dino horde survival shooter with one of the most ambitious developers backing it to create a great universe that expands from where the game currently is to everything they’ve ever wanted from a game, all for the low low price of a buck.  With solid gameplay today, it’s well worth the purchase while you wait for the rest.  It’s easily a few hours of content now for a casual game hopper, and a hundred or more for a dedicated fan.

It's a top down shooter...  No, it's a third person shooter...  No, it's a first person shooter!  You've got a range of shooting options, full controller support for all three perspectives, and a lot of variety for dinosaurs to slaughter.  It's missing a small bit of polish in some minor areas, but the devs have great ambition and have proven with past titles that they definitely won't give up until it's to their liking.

Currently it’s got “protect the harvester” and “survival” game modes, but they have more coming within the next couple months and a campaign mode coming by 2017.  For those of you who don’t like slaughtering dinosaurs, we’re getting robot enemies too.

But that’s not what you care about today, ‘cause every game promises big.  So here’s what you get for a dollar today (MSRP as of writing):
Dino horde survival co-op in top down/third person/first person perspectives.
Solid character progression through loot and levels.
Free currency to gamble with for chances at getting loot outside of missions.
Daily/weekly “quests” to earn premium currency, leaving nothing behind a paywall, not even cosmetics.
Solid controls with tight response times, resulting in great feeling gameplay.
A visually appealing unreal 4 game, beautiful from all perspectives.
Creative character customization in both serious and silly ways.
Access to all future ‘games’ within The Orion Project. -  An insane amount of content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Guardians of Orion:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The cargo doors are about to open…. From above, everything looks pretty calm and your mission is to protect the harvester that will collect blue gold. But, it will not be a walk in the park (so to speak) as you and your teammates know exactly what sort of beasts are down there…. Damn right you know, it is full of dinosaurs and some robots ready to take you down and apart!

Guardians of Orion is a top down co-op  action / shooter game where you take control of one of four Guardians and push back 10 waves of dinosaurs coming at you and at the harvester you trying to protect. At this stage, you have the choice of 3 types of guardian: Assault, Support and Recon. Each one has a special ability:

1.	A Jetpack for the Assault class, which is superb when the dinosaurs are charging at you - use your jetpack to avoid the destructive impact and discharge a volley of bullets from above.
2.	 A bubble of Heal for the Support class, deploy it and your health will regenerate quickly for you and for your teammates.
3.	Invisibility for the Recon class, it will be hard for them to see and therefore to hurt you.

Also, each class has its own specific weapons; I personally like the Assault classes with the auto rifle and pistol. Another important item in your inventory is the Regen gun which can repair the harvester and heal you as well as your teammates.

As you battle the dinosaurs and robots, colour orbs will appear where your enemies have fallen - run over it and you will get a booster, such as speed firing, XP double points, damage increase and more. However, they will only last a short time.

Each character will have a display with 4 different colour bars on the bottom left of your screen. You will be able to see your health, shield, harvester status and, most importantly, the XP bars. As you kill more and more enemies, you will collect points and sooner rather than later you will fill the entire bar and level up.  Then you will be able to add some skills to your character, weaponry and miscellaneous sections through the Skill Tree.

There is a good amount of gore in this game, where you can see a dinosaur head going one way and its body the other way upon its death. You will encounter and fight up to 10 variety of dinosaurs.

In this version, you will be able to play in 4 different maps either in a Solo game or online co-op. From the control point of view, they are easy to master. The only thing I would like to see is a better target icon. The graphics are really good as well as the soundtrack.

Additional guardian class and dinosaurs coming in 2016.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Great graphics
-	Fun and easy to play
-	Good variety of dinosaurs
-	In games achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~~

-	Better target display
-	No trading cards

I am really enjoying this game and I look forward to playing the new class of guardians and fighting new dinosaurs!

8.5/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access first impressions:

The graphics are beautiful. The sound design is top notch. Coming from ORION: Prelude, the gameplay almost made me feel at home. I'm not used to playing with a controller (Xbox 360), but the controls are smooth and responsive. Rolled away from and whooped a T-rex in single combat. This is just about what I was expecting.

07 March 2016 EDIT: I've moved on from the Xbox 360 controller and have become established with the mouse and keyboard. Also switched from top down to 3rd person over the shoulder view (Press F1) for deeper immersion. Addition of item drops and crafting turns this game into Diablo Lite.

Initial sales were extremely disappointing and development efforts were nearly abandoned. The dev team regrouped and has re-committed to turning this into one of the very finest products available on Steam. First person view, vehicles, new maps, weapons, boss fights, game modes, more classes, spaceships and galactic travel are all confirmed for development. This is already shaping up to be a fun game and it is going to develop into one hell of a product before its time is up.

Pick up Founder status before May 2016 for the best value. Also check out Trek Industries on YouTube for frequent giveaways.

a $1 game, with more content than some $60 game (you know which one i'm talking about), with regular updates, and continuous support by the developers, its currently in update v1.4 which supports Tps viewpoint, a new map, and some optimization, but by the time anyone read this, it should be in v1.5 or higher, Its a massive improvement from Orion: Prelude, Graphics have been improved, gameplay, movement, the Dinosaur AI, and its only $1

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very, very bare bones right now, but still one of the better early access games I have ever played. It has a lot of potential and I am really excited to see how it shapes up. For now, the $20 is a big risk because nobody knows how much content they plan to add. Since it is so minimal, the current sale price of $2 is a better time to get it because right now it is pretty much just equal to a tech demo. The gameplay is solid but the UI needs a lot of improving. The sounds are great and the music is some of the best I have heard in a long time in a game.

Pick it up on sale, otherwise wait for the release to see how much content it has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy! They've improved so much since Orion:Prelude!
This game is still in early acess but it's beautiful in it's graphics, great playability/mechanics and AWESOME soundtrack's!
It's a very fun and challenging game, it really gets friends together for a good play and laugh.
The devs are updating the game every month with a bunch of improvements, new mechanics, dinosaurs, gear, fixing bugs, etc...
Im disconsidering the bug's in this analysis since i didn't experiencie any fatal/gameplay compromising bugs and it's a early acess game. Maybe the only downside i see right now it's the amount of content it has, but since the launch of it's early acess is so recent, i really dont complain about it.
The devs are also in touch with the community so the games gets better, i really apreciate this.
So, if you are like me and like shotting dinosaurs in the face, this is THE GAME!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A note about the developer

I used to reccomend this game. I love the game and I supported David and the Orion IP since Orion: Dino Beatdown. The game review will be below this, but I want to talk about David Prassel. David Prassel claims to be very supportive and rewarding to his community, which is sometimes true. However, if you disagree with anything, think something should change, have any criticism, or even sometimes report a bug, he will lash out at you with insults and overall immature behavior and often time bans. Many people agree with this, and many of those people have been banned. Luckily those bans do not extend to reviews.

http://steamcommunity.com/id/drunken_drake/recommended/407840/

This review is a good example. Take note of Davids comment on the second page.

http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-04-18-orion-dino-horde-dev-hits-back-at-allegations-of-metacritic-manipulation

David Prassel is known for banning people and locking threads to those who speak against him. All you need to do to be banned is have an opposing opinion or offer some advice that he disagrees with.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/407840/discussions/0/357284767253434903/?ctp=2

http://steamcommunity.com/app/407840/discussions/0/357287304421019351/?ctp=2

There is plenty evidence that he resorts to insulting his community as well as banning them. He has said Lucky for you we don't do game bans
date:
only community-based bans as I believe opinions sometimes need to be earned." However.

http://i.imgur.com/ioyo5XA.png

http://i.imgur.com/D13vbJU.png

Not ONLY did he ban this user from the forums and from The Orion Project
recommended: he threatened him and his family by saying he has called the police and given the police information against him and his family. Like what the ♥♥♥♥? He claims harassment but actively trying to make the community know his lies
voteText: and ban abuse is not harassment. He even set a bounty on him and attempted to start a witch hunt to find him. Unfortunately for him
helpfulPercent: he didn't take the post down in time so now you get to see it. "Just know this isn't over." That is not a threat. It's a statement saying that David Prassel's bull ♥♥♥♥ won't end here
votesHelpful: and he's right. I won't tell you to not support him
votesTotal:
but I urge you to consider everything he has said and done and decide for yourself whether or not you want to support this kind of behavior.

------

Quick Orion IP History and Evolution

Spiral Games Studios started off with a hell of a launch. They released Orion: Dino Beatdown to steam and it was recieved with a TON of negative feedback. I bought it and honestly could entirely understand why
votesFunny: though I still had fun with it. It eventually became Orion: Dino Horde
commentsCount: which was a slightly better version of beatdown. Awhile after that it became Orion: Prelude. By this point the game improved a lot. It gained a lot more content
column17: and became a really enjoyable game
column18: as well as hit the low price of $1. The Orion Project is their next game and wow
column19: I'm blown away. One thing
column20: however
column21: they do tend to market their game as what it will be
column22: rather than what it is.\n\nThe Orion Project is a massive step up in quality. There's much more in depth mechanics
column26: and impressive world design. The roadmap for this game is impressive
column27: but I think totally believable. According to SteamDB
column30: 000 owners. That's a good amount of income. They also are about to hit 100
column31: 000 with The Orion Project. Assuming David Presson and his team stay true to their promises
column32: this game will be one hell of a thing. It's on its way to being a Destiny Esque RPG Shooter Exploration game with space travel
column35:
and more.

-----

Actual Game Review

On to the game. It plays pretty well. there's a good amount of maps
column37: 3 skill trees with varying skills depending on the class
column39: a interesting and well built crafting system
column40: and a wide variety of enemies ranging from Dinosaurs to Android robots. Each Guardian has a 50 level cap and each a unique set of weapons. It's very enjoyable to play and supports a Third Person over the shoulder view point or a Top Down Twinstick style view point. First Person View will be released in May 2016 as well as quests and I'm sure a lot of other content. The game is planned to be supported with monthly updates and so far they have delivered. My first time playing I ended up playing for 8 hours straight and I've been addicted to the game since. It has a social aspect
column41: where players are placed on an orbital command station in a lobby with a bunch of other players. Here you can check the leaderboards
column44: and party up with players.\n\nCurrently there are two gameplay modes
column45: Harvest and Survival. Harvest is a 10 wave survival-like mode where you follow and defend a harvester collection Ion crystals
column46: the main currency. Every few waves there is a side objective consisting of harder enemies and bosses with loot chests as a reward. Survival is similar to Harvest
column47: except the harvester is in a static location and the waves are endless. Survival has a lower Augment (equipment) drop rate and no loot chests
column50: and competing in the leaderboards.\n\nThe Orion Project does have some short comings
column51: though. A great example is the never failing sequence of freezes when you first get the game. To play online
column52: you are required to make an account which is very easy to set up and requires no activation. However
column53: during the first launch you will end up in a infinite loading screen which you must close. The second launch
column54: when you attempt to sign in it will infinitely attempt to sign in and must close. The third launch works 90% of the time
column56: and you'll be able to play.\n\nSome players report having massive stuttering during game and freezes. For some
column58: others cannot find a fix and so far have not recieved any attention from the developers. This bug seems to be for a minority
column59: though.\n\nOccasionally after signing in you will get kicked to the menu
column61:
sometimes enough to not be able to play. Most of the time this will go away on its own and I assume it's issues with their servers. There is also a chance of being kicked to the menu when you try and launch the game.

----

Conclusion

Do I recommend this game? Short answer
column62: Yes. The game in its current state is buggy
column64: and may require some patience. However
column65: it is fun as hell. It has enough content to keep you going for awhile and is a great game for coop with friends or even randoms. I usually don't enjoy being paired with random players in coop games but this one is an exception. I highly recommend this game if you are fine with experiencing some bugs and setbacks and want a really enjoyable shooter with in depth loot and crafting mechanics and/or want to support development and see this game grow. I don't reccomend this game in its current state if you have a low end machine (needs optimization)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: 8,7/10 This is a quite astonishing game, a must buy if you like Dinos and Saurs.

I bought this game for 1€! Yeah, one WHOLE €, that's quite alot.... I guess. Yeah, I got this for dirt cheap, and to be honest, at first, this game probably wasn't worth much more, but in that short time of about 6 months the developers added really flashy cool ♥♥♥♥ to this game that can be cheesy at times but for the most it's just awesome.

Pros/Cons

+Literally blasting away dinos with shotguns, rocket launchers and flamethrowers, or shooting flying bird dinos from the sky with a magnum.
+Masses of enemies to slice and dice your way through.
+Nice enemy design ideas, like the Namor, hope Trek does more with that base.
+It's dirt cheap.
+IT GOT HATS AND COSMETICS! OHHH MY GOOD YEEEEEEEEE!
+Loot system
+Starting lobby, I think it's pretty cool.
+Plenty of maps (and upcoming gamemodes!)
+Plenty of Characters.
--------------------------------
+/- Cheesiest voice acting ever, kinda makes me laugh though.
+/- There are two currencies, ingame earnable money and money by steam wallet, the real money version hopefully only is for cosmetics tho, crossing my fingers.
+/- Quite difficult for a FPS player to first get into the controls, but after a time you really get used to it, tho.
--------------------------------
-Not finished.
-Does have bugs.
-Not the best optimization.

My overall verdict: 8.7/10 Surely, it seems like this is a perfect game, and yes, for the price, it truly is, definitely worth checking out, but overall, in a complete game standpoint it's surely not the best, but yeah, not every game deserves 10/10, that's as good as impossible anyway. (Note, added bonus on the verdict for the stones Trek has to 1. updating Orion till it's actually good and 2. Having the stones to make fun of it and 3. Bringing out another game... that's actually fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start with the pro's first

-3rd person xtreme dino action, now with even more dino

-ultra dino action mode coming to an fps near you

-if the dino's want to eat you the robots want to dissect you, starwars episode 2 looking at you

-there is now an insane lobby, possibly the most impressive lobby ever created.
Go ahead test your box kicking skills

-someday we'll be able to see whats beyound that dusty hill outside, yes open world will be a thing

-according to the developers, its open space.  Um spaceships?  Yes please!

-you can have a party in the lobby with 30 other dudes just hanging around talking

-did i mention boxs?  many many box's, oh what joy they are to bounce them off other players heads

-awesome skill tree and already many character classes

-lots and lots of loot, if there was any more loot you'd become a hobo space pirate marine

ok so whats bad about it?

So far the only really bad thing is that the game is still quite early, basically where its heading is part of David's overall vision to create an mmo.  Many of the ideas that are now being implemented come from the failed orion project on kickstarter which failed because it did not meet the funding goal.  Instead of floundering David kept up his stride and just kept hammering away at this.  Its also on UE4 the graphics are impressive even now.

I must also add despite what some may of heard this isn't going to be Starcitizen on steam there is literally no game that can be this.  I wont go into the reasons why on this review, but i will say that Guardians of orion - the mmo it will eventually be will be worth every dollar you spend on it get it before it has a price increase which will likely happen.

Do you like the idea of unreal tournament combined with an mmo then dinos and killer robots thrown in the mix?  In a nut shell thats where this is heading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I already can't say enough good about this game.

First, as much fun as I had with Orio Dino Horde for $1, I felt these guys deserved my $10 on that alone.

I was a little worried about seeing it as isometric, but you know what? It really works well! The graphics are good, the controls are smooth (using 360 controller) and the music is absolutely fantastic (I actually wouldn't mind a soundtrack DLC once it is all done).

The developer said he designed the game based on him and his fiance liking to co-op together. My wife and I have played a few rounds of this already and had a blast so I can completely see that.

Game needs more game modes, weapons, and maps but it is early access and what is already there is surprisingly polished. I am especially impressed with the great early controller support.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For $0.99 this is an absolute steal of a game. There's not a set end goal to the gameplay other than unlocking more and more things and upgrading. Any fan of Borderlands games would love this game.

The loot system isn't exactly the best, but it's very early access. There's a few bugs, however none of my friends (or I) have run into game-breaking ones. The servers aren't great either, but once again it's just early access.

Also for $0.99 you get a game that is very regularly updated, and a very large project. The developers seem to really love interacting with users. There's also a Steam Workshop in the works for this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am not sure of the issues other may be experiencing but two of my friends and myself have little to no issue playing at all. Unless you count the odd lag spiks and unusual reactions of some enemy’s when approaching wave 40 in survival. I can definitely chalk that up to “it's alpha” reasoning. Adding to that that the lag is often short lived bit often showing at some of the most inopportune times. The levels do get a bit grindy and the initial break in to each new difficulty and gear range can be VERY irritating. I am not holding my breath for a revolutionary game that will redefine the gaming industry and taking the developers history in to account I did not expect this game to even get this far. With that statement in mind I do believe any issues with the company, if any did exist, are now behind them and I see the possibility of a very bright future for this game. I plan to continue to play with friends for quite some time. I will attempt to update this as time goes on just for the purpose of making sure bad updates don't drown out the good ones like the previous game. I work in the very broad field of IT and believe me when I say very rarely will people comment positively on good work (I like to think they are enjoying it too much), but when things are out of place everyone complains.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am really impressed by this game so far.
It still is early in its development phase so if you are not fond of early access you might not like that.
I bought it on sale and it really feels like a steal.

Let's go with the classic pros and cons:
Pros:
-It has dinosaurs!
-It has already five classes
-the multiplayer is good, i have not experienced any lag so far.
-It looks rather good, it could be better but it is really far from ugly.
-It has a lot of loot, and an interesting crafting system.
-it has a decent amount of weapons and this will get better with time.
-it can be pretty intense with 4 players
-it is objective based, i mean yes it is a simple horde game, but you know why you are camping: to defend a harvester
wich makes me think of the one in the command and conquer serie so i can't really complain.
-You will fight against a T-rex and many other bosses ;)

Cons:
-Poorly optimised, i can run it on max settings at around 40 fps with a gtx970, which is a bit annoying, especially if you have even worse hardware. The game looks good but not good enough to justify the low fps i am getting.
-Grindy, well yes it was to be excpected but still pretty damn grindy.
Pretty boring when playing solo.
-It needs more variety especially class wise and gear wise, but it is early access so it should be expected.
-It can be repetitive, but well it is an horde game so you know what you are buying right ;)
-3rd person view, i personaly hate that as i prefer the fps style, but you can also switch with a top down view if you think it is unbearable.
Tl;DR:
This game has a lot of potential, i recommend buying it on sale, but if the devs keep on working on it as they started this could become a classic.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me start over, because I was being a bit unfair. The game it's self is being headed by an indie developer with big dreams who's last title, Orion: Prelude was once the worst pc game on the market which eventually evolved into one of the best indie $1 games on Steam. What this game badly needs is more story. There are several classes all with unique abilities, but if you were not a founder you will have to work hard or pay out of pocket to unlock these other classes. Though the game is quite limited, expect much more gameplay variety and unique features. For now, you may burn yourself out playing the game too much with the two modes that are offered. I reccomend playing every now and again and checking back as new features are added. Of course, that's not what I did at all. I got pretty addicted, as it is a very addicting game. Now,  I bought this game for $10 and a week later the price dropped to $1 so I wish I had waited. It's worth $1. Maybe, in time, it will be worth $10 or heck even $50. What I want to see is the developers focusing more on lore, story and unique features. They say they are dreaming big, and that they want this game to be a big contender. I've heard these words before spoken in what were once great ideas and now ghost-towns of games. You'll enjoy it, you might get bored at the end of the night from killing Dinos. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Considering that this game is still in Early Access, I have greatly enjoyed it so far. At the moment there are 3 classes and they all seem relatively balanced.

The Assault Class-Has high mobility and kiting with his jetpack. Uses an Assault Rifle.
The Support Class (Main and Fave Class)-Boosts in healing and repairing the Harvester. With the help of the Trusty Shotgun has some decent spread damage.
The Recon Class-Can lose Dino Aggro in a split second with her Cloak mechanic. Uses the silenced SMG for some awesome long range single target damage. If specked right her emp grenades can do some pretty heavy damage too.

Right now the only mode available is Survival. In this mode you protect this slowly moving machine called the Harvester while it collects ores throughout the map. While protecting the Harvester you will be slaughtering waves of dino/robotic enemies. This may be relatively repetitive for some, seeing your class level up and progress through their various skill trees makes it worth while.

And again please note that this isn't the full release, the development team is quite active on working on new content, adding new classes, new enemies and new modes and fixing bugs that the community reports. This game is definitely worth a try with some friends. In it's current state I don't really know if it's worth the $20 price tag, but once complete I'm sure it will be. Taking advantage of the steam sales or (like I did) take advantage of the free copy promotions that Trek Industries has been doing would be worth it. This game has a lot of potential and I look forward to seeing how it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow, what a neat looking Early Access game!

First of all, I'm a huge co-op game fan so I picked this game up along with a couple of friends just like every other person.
I bought it because I heard a lot of great things about the Devs and that they actually cared about feedback and constantly updating the game on a regular basis - which they do!

Overall, with the game being an Early Access title, it does seem  quite bare and simple in terms of the UI and content/gameplay.  However, as the Dev Team have mentioned before, they are hard at work on creating new content (check their News section and you'll see).

Cons: -

So you have idk how many classes in the game, and most of them are pretty generic.  Every class has a healing gun so that pretty much makes the 'medic' useless.  Each class also has their own special ability; and while most of them seem pretty lackluster, at least they have one.  There is also one ability that everyone has - the 'Blink', much like 'Flash' in League of Legends, or a simple, short ranged teleportation spell.
OVERALL, the classes seem a bit bare-bones AT THE MOMENT, but I'm sure they will be improved with some sort of UNIQUE mechanics that actually involves some tactical or skill gameplay.

- There is also no West coast server, so there is a bit of lag.  But that's alright.
- User Interface (UI) seem very basic and simple-looking.  Aesthetically, it needs a bit of jazzing up.
- Crafting system is kinda weird and complicated at first glance.
- Controls are weird, so check them in the Options menu before you play to familiarize yourself!

PROS!

- One of the most fun co-op games on Steam imo, and it is very easy to pick up and play!  The gameplay is top-down, a lot like Helldivers, but guess what? YOU CAN ALSO SWITCH TO 3RD PERSON VIEW, which looks WAY more awesome! press F2 or something.  Check the controls!

- Constantly being updated, and Devs are transparent enough.
- Fun, engaging combat that isn't too hard to learn, and is fun to roll/blink around your enemies!
- Has an RPG-like SKILL TREE for each class, so it feels rewarding to level up!
- Graphics look very good, especially in 3rd person view.

OVERALL imo a 7.5/10 (I bought this on Sale btw), may even rise to a 8.5-9 if the Devs flesh out this game more, it has a LOT OF potential...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of now, Buying into the early access is $1.

Even if the game were to die today, it is easily worth that price. 4 player local co-op survival and defense missions, with a crafting, loot and leveling system. I only started to scratch the surface of the game, and it seems solid, controller support, leveling, items, fairly balanced enemies, a variety of difficulties.. all improved upon from the previous ORION game.

But the developers still intend to imput tons more stuff. This game seeks to build off previous work on ORION: Prelude, which was in itself a pretty great game. And this means they want to take an existing frame work and include more classes, enemies, community features and game modes. Not to mention the ability to explore a galaxy and some really cool set piecies in the game.


Just looking at that list in the game description, then look up at the price. Now back to the list, now back to the price.

Buy into the game for $1.. Because really, what is there to loose?

Answer: One dollar.

EDIT: Other Final thoughts, this is a developer who has consistently made thier games unbelivably affordable, charging crazy low prices in a world where games with half the polish and half the commitment go on sale for twice the price.. One dollar for early access? Seems crazy.. paradigm shifting and a breath of fresh air in a time filled with high game prices that seem to rise by $10 every year,

I wish the development team at TREK only the best in their endeavours, I know I will be following along.

FURTHER EDIT:
The developers announced today that the game was going to get a community panel implemented next year to act as a sort of moderator and lore building group for the world. Now that is some cutting edge stuff there. My only complaint from the last game was that I had absolutely no idea what happened to get me where I was.. Right now it seems all those questions are going to be answered by the community. Seriously, community elections while still in early access (albiet down the line, but still)?  Raising the bar TREK, raising the bar.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is interesting despite its shortfalls which I'll discuss later in this review.

First, I'd like to point out how early we're getting this game.  There are basic, core features promised in the description which are not present in the current build of the game.  Early access is almost an understatement.  However, do not let that deter you from buying the game.

Second, I'd like to point out that the game is currently on sale for $0.99 and is worth all ninety nine pennies.  Buy it if you're thinking about it.

Now, the review:

I'm not going to give a list of pros and cons because this game is expected to change drastically, and hopefully my review along with it.  I will simply mention the things in this game that make it worth playing and things that make it not worth playing, just things that I happened to note throughout my experience.

As a top-down shooter, it succeeds.  The controls are intuitive and feel familiar, yet they're refined to work in both third-person and top-down mode.  I would recommend remapping the blink key (default 'c' I believe) to something that your right hand can hit quickly; preferably on your mouse.  Blink often, this is a feature of the game that will make it much easier and will probably be nerfed at some point.

Let's talk about the third-person shooter aspect.  Press F1 to toggle between top-down and third-person.  I was excited for this feature, but quickly realized that I'm at a slight disadvantage because I can't see the miniature dinosaurs through the grass, whereas in top-down you can see them coming from quite far away.  There is one advantage though, which is that you can easily take down the flying dinosaurs before they can even attack you.  That's really about it, though.  And the flying dinosaurs aren't even that big of an issue unless they're in large numbers, which they rarely are.  The mouse feels funky.  Aiming does not feel good in third-person.  I've removed mouse acceleration (or whatever the setting is called ingame) and it still feels like there's some latency between when I move the mouse and when my character looks around.  It's very difficult to aim in this game, but luckily, aiming isn't important.  Your stock weapons can kill mostly anything on your level within 1-2 hits depending on your class.  Shotguns are 1-hit kill on all lower level mobs.  I recommend using the support class if you're new to top-down shooters.  It is very intuitive.

The graphics are really not impressive, but I'm not complaining about them either.  There is some customization, but not a whole lot.  I turn them down because it seems to reduce the foliage which makes it easier to kill the tiny little dinos.

Crafting appears to be fully implemented and from my limited experience with it, it seems very well-done.  The menus work, I haven't experienced any bugs with it, and it seems to be easy to teach yourself how the crafting system works without much (if any?) guidance.  Your inventory has an intuitive sorting function which I love.  Makes things very easy to read.

Features missing from the game...major.  This is major.  But, luckily, I know for a fact that they're coming, so I'm not upset that my $0.99 game is missing a few major, core features.  Open world?  No sir.  Travel the galaxy?  Not even a little bit.  Persistent universe?  Where?  Living, breathing?  Let's call it...not living, or breathing.  The game isn't finished, guys.  I can't comment on these aspects of the game because it simply lacks these features entirely.

So, that's pretty much my review.  If you're curious, and reading this later in time and now have the fully fleshed out game, then let me explain what it's like now.  You spawn in, and there's (I think?) a tutorial to show you how to do some basic stuff.  There might not be, I really don't remember.  But you enter this unknown space station in an unknown location, with zero identifying features, and you're told...nothing.  Nothing about how to start games or what you're even supposed to do.  Through asking people, I discovered that there is a strategy table where I can start a matchmade game, or another table nearby where I can craft, although crafting is all done through your inventory anyways so these hubs are utterly pointless.  So, the only thing you can do is start a game right now.  You can control the map, the difficulty, the item level requirement, and a few other things as well.  There are two game types to choose from at the moment, survival and harvest.  Survival is classic wave survival, dinos just keep attacking you until you can't hold out anymore.  Harvest is a bit different, but same-ish concept.  A harvester travels around the map harvesting an unknown material, and you must defend it from waves of attackers.  Occasionally a chest will appear, guarded by more powerful mobs.  All drops are personal, meaning no one can just steal a chest from you and get all the items while you get none.  Everybody gets their own randomized drops.  There are also powerups in the game, giving you things like running speed, shooting speed, etc.

Anyways, as it stands, this game is hard to play consistently.  It's very grindy, but there are multiple maps to choose from.  Around 4-5 maps iirc.  Far from open-world, far from living/breathing, and far from completion, but a promising game worth $0.99 nonetheless.  In this state, I'd give the game a 5/10.  Enough to buy it, not enough to play it for over 100 hours yet.  If it had all the promised features, I predict an easy 8/10, and if they fix the mouse latency issue, 9/10.  Implement PvP = 10/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo far a great up and coming game. Graphically does better on my system than most other games. At 1440 resolution I can run everything on Super High/Ultra with a GTX 970 and get around 60 fps with the occassional dips and rises. All other games that are graphically similar I'd only be able to play on High graphics at 1440 resolution. Being able to switch from first person to a top down view with F1 is pretty neat. It can really help sometimes depending on the situation in game. Guardians of Orion is very similar to Orion Prelude but it takes everything MUCH further. AND it's still being avidly developed and expanded, which is always great news. It does have some traits that are completely different than Prelude as well. For one, it now has a strong arcade feel both due to the optional top down view and from the loot collecting. Also, the waves of enemies seem to spawn much snappier here regardless of mode. The enemies have far more character in this game too. And the second main difference, Guardians has expanded on Prelude's RPG elements. Along with this new loot collecting there is item crafting (it's fairly simple so don't let that be a turn off) and a 3D character portrait surrounded by empty equipment slots to be filled with new gear typical to an RPG game. I found all of this to be pretty cool. There is an in-game money system that uses ions" of which you collect as you play and destroy enemies. By the way
date: the main goal  of the game as of right now is to protect your harvester
recommended: a machine that travels around the new world harvesting minerals. There are many character types to choose from. OH
hoursPlayed: and there is a skill tree. It's nothing crazy
voteText: kind of reminds me of Borderlands' skill tree as far as the layout goes. Gameplay is very smooth. There is a roll/dodge feature instead of the normal jump with spacebar which surprised me but I easily got used to it. A new Quests feature is supposed to be released in April 2016. An update added a central hub when you start the online game. I like this a lot
helpfulPercent: it reminds me of Phantasy Star Online I and II because that game had a central hub stationed in outerspace too
votesHelpful: although the graphics are very different nowadays... Sidenote: I especially love the music in this game as I did in Phantasy Star. Hmm
votesTotal: lastly
votesFunny: Guardians of Orion does appear to have an offline mode for local play of up to 4 people. I didn't get to try this but I would love to see if that works. This game is very promising as of right now and in my opnion worth the $10 asking price."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point in time, I am seriously 50/50 on the whole situation. On one hand, this game isn't and wasn't ready, there are so many features missing that even Prelude in it's current state is better. Then again, one of the developers sold his god damn car to make sure Prelude transformed from a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ disaster to actually being a fun game that I destroyed my free time with. They are promising ALOT of things, and I really want this game to succeed, because all I believe is that these devs need a good foot. So devs, please listen up, if you really want to get people invested early, I want you to do some stuff.

1: Add vehicles, what made Prelude pretty fun and crazy WAS vehicles. Please give us those back.

2: Balance out the item system, I find it really stupid that item drops are determined on how difficult your mission is, instead of how high of a level you are. You can just start out on the game and get level 500s if you have some friends to help you, that isn't the way to go.

3: Upgrade servers or actually let us host our own connections, I get literally 100 ping on servers in the east coast in america, that's unacceptable since I only live a couple states away, upgrade the servers or please just let us host our own servers. One will actually save you a lot of bandwidth.

4: Have workshop support and encourage it, the thing I love about games is being able to download tons of workshop content and then be able to play them for the night. It shows that not only do you care about your community, but it also shows that the community is here to help shape the game.

5: Continue to show that you actively care for the game, seriously one of your guys sold his ♥♥♥♥ing car to continue development on Prelude? I'm not saying to destroy your life for us, but continue to inspire and amaze with what you can do, even if it has no future of hope.

Remember your own words devs, games cant fail

recommended: and I can promise you something
hoursPlayed: I will certainly continue playing it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first saw this game I was a bit disappointed, I really enjoy Orion: Prelude and figured this was going to be basically the next step up from the co-op FPS Dinosaur blasting experience, but it was a top down shooter? But I kept tabs on it anyway just to watch the development.

Then one day I checked to see a big update. 3rd person view added? Not only that, but switching between top down and 3rd person view on the fly with a hotkey? Open world in development? Wait, what, not just open world but open galaxy? And now it's only $1? Hell yes I'm in. The optimization is kinda bad currently but they're working on it, and I've found the top down mode is actually pretty fun and I switch between them frequently. I normally use top down for small waves because the tiny dinos are hard to spot in 3rd person, but they're easy to pick out from above.

To add to that the devs frequently ask for player input and actually listen. Honestly this would have been a purchase for me even at the original price after the 3rd person update, but at $1 it's an absolute steal. If you enjoyed Orion: Prelude picking this up is almost a must, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary of our Review:

The game plays fairly typically to a standard top down shooter with some rpg elements. The game starts out with an offline mode and an online mode. The offline mode is the same as online except restricted to local co-op or single player. Wait, local co-op? Seriously? You, you offered local co-op? Gotta be honest here, we’re surprised. A nice surprise as local co-op is getting more and more rare in the PC gaming scene as of late.

To start the game online, you create an account. After that, it will sign you in, sign you into steam, and you’re off. You’ll spawn in a main hub world where you can buy items and crafting materials, talk to players, join other servers, create parties, etc. We don’t believe there’s native support for microphones, but we’re not quite sure. No one we played with talked except in the chat menu during our time with the game. To start playing, choose a class you want to play as (we chose support for his shield ability and shotgun) and you then level up. Each class you chose levels up independently, but the items and crafting materials you obtain from the store or during missions are universal to all the classes. The crafting is fairly limited, and we mainly just crafted things that give us a bonus to XP, as well as crafting some legendary items. You have common items (no color) below your level (green) at your level (yellow) and legendary weapons (purple). You can also craft or find armor pieces or bonuses to your class’ special power. Weapons and armors will give different bonuses for different things. In example, a level 300 chest piece may have 500 defense and add 200 intelligence, but a level 310 chest piece may add 550 defense but add 150 strength and so on. Legendary items often have special traits such as bonus gold finding or certain things that once hurt you healing you.

Despite some gripes with the game, we enjoyed our time with it. It often reminded me of the older Turok games, as well as the Turok comic series. It’s not totally fleshed out, but we still enjoyed killing triceratops and getting murdered and eaten by t-rexes. We enjoyed the large variety of classes to choose from, and we enjoyed the nice variety of augments and abilities you can find. We wish you could sell unwanted items in the shop, and we hope that will be an upcoming feature at some point. While it is enjoyable, it’s clear that the focus is multiplayer, and it’s far better with a friend or two by your side.

For what it’s worth, we really like the concept of the game. While not the most solid early access game out there, it certainly got our attention. Would we have purchased it at $9.99 as it is? Probably not, but it’s still a decent game nonetheless and plays well. While not the most stable, it’s stable enough to play, enjoy, and remember a time when the only dinosaur related things involved either Jurassic Park, or a native American, mind controlled dinosaurs, and evil humans .

PROS
- A top down shooter done right
- Excellent diversity of character stats
- Great music

CONS
- More voice acting
- larger diversity of maps and enemies
- Fix controller support

Overall: 7.3/10

For our full review, click here: http://yourwolfsdengaming.com/2016/04/14/guardians-of-orion-early-access-review/

- If your objective is located gruading a harvester"
date: then enemies should not run away from you OR you should have a teleport to harvester option.  This happens on timed missions to kill things.  But they seem to sometimes run away and sometimes meander.  Though once you are in range they start chasing you.  It doesn't feel like the challenge is to catch them in time
recommended: it feels like wonky AI that takes you out of the immersion.  The larger problem is how tedious it is to run back to the harvester.\n- Crafting menu needs LOTS of work.  It seems to be oversaturated with refinements over end results.  Categories could use work.  But probably the biggest thing is when you mouse over components
hoursPlayed: it should give you info or at least let you cross link to them by clicking on them.  It should go both ways
voteText: such that when you are on a craftable thing
helpfulPercent: it should show you what is needed to make it
votesHelpful: and what it can be used for to make other things.  This is just information and organization.\n- It's far too cnsole centric.  From minor things like a useless splash screen if you are mouse/keyboard (showing you gamepad controls on PC even if you don't have a gamepad plugged in... lots of small development games make an assumption of what control type you are using based on what you have plugged in).  To larger things like not being able to type your name into a new save game field (you click on letters with mouse / gamepad).  This larger issue makes the game feel like PC was an afterthought.  Fortunately the gameplay feels fine.  But the tedious nature of these other things is a big negative to me personally as I feel this is representative of a build philosophy that isn't in line with my play philosophy.  It's fine that these games exist
votesTotal: but it makes me favor those in line with my play style (and who wouldn't look for games of their play style).\n- Inventory menu could use work.  Just the basic thing of highlighting the slot something you are dragging goes into.  This has been a stable of UI for a long time
