reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have high hopes for this game. The devs seem involved and committed to this project and it seems like we already have a good community built. The devs have a long-term plan for the game with great ideas and tons of exciting new content will be released in the next two years. The game is super cheap and really is worth it. As soon as I played it for the first time I thought to myself: Jurassic Park meets Halo! Epicness. I would recommend this game to anyone.

Pros:

- The devs are involved and committed to the game.
- Good community.
- First person mode coming soon!
- Awesome music.
- Upgrades and skill trees.
- Enemy variety.
- Ragdoll physics.
- Hats!
- Loads of exciting new content being released in the future!

Cons:

- I kind of liked the game's old name better, but oh well.
- There is a premium currency, but this might not even be an issue.
- I don't know if this is just me, but the graphics seem to need work. Forced to choose between lag or low resolution.

All in all, great game and looking forward to seeing where the devs go with it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start this by saying this is one of my all time favorite games at the moment. I received a free copy from the Devs during a giveaway on YouTube on Dec 4, 2015 to test, review it and give feedback. I couldn't play it that much back then because of exams and life etc.. The game has a lot of potential and the Devs truly care about their community, fans and game, and are always in touch with and involving the community in the game's development, which earns them A LOT of respect and makes me want to support them. I bought 2 extra copies of the game to support them and the development of the game that I believe has a bright future.


Now back to the review,


What is The Orion Project (aka Guardians of Orion)?
The Orion Project is/will be a little bit similar to it's predecessor, ORION: Prelude, but with Improved Graphics, Animations, Top-Down and Third-Person Views, New Maps, Game Lobby Space Station where you meet other players and chat with them, Crafting, Character Skill Tree, Inventory.


Game Modes
The current available Modes are Harvest and Survival.

Harvest Mode you will have to face and kill several types Dinosaurs and Creatures defending yourself, teammates and the Harvester, which will be moving around collecting ION each wave.

Survival Mode you will have to face and kill several types Dinosaurs and Creatures defending yourself and teammates and survive all the waves.


Classes
There are 7 Classes/Guardians available to choose from:

Assault
Support
Recon
Tech
Pyro
Marksman
Rocketeer
And each class comes with it's own Equipment and Abilities.


Maps
There are currently 6 maps available to choose from with Day/Night time options.

Relic
OutBack
Arid
Summit
WhiteOut
Haven

Difficulty Levels
Easy
Normal
Hard
Insane
Redikulous (Nope, that's not a typo)

Ingame Stores
There are two stores ingame, none of which give you any gameplay advantage over other players.

The ION Store has 4 Tabs

Euipment
Consumables
Materials
Roulette

The Equipment tab has three types of LockBoxes that containing enhanced pieces of gear and legendary items.

The Consumables tab has Health and Shield Packs as well as an instant XP gain.

The Materials tab has crafting materials.

The Roulette tab has several Gem and Material Packs to choose from.

The Trek Store has three Tabs

Hats
Skins
XP Boosts
The Hats tab has a variety of hats to choose from.
The Skins tab has a number of cool looking uniform re-skins to make you look good on the field of battle.
The XP Boosts has, as you already guessed, XP Boosts for those who'd like to level up their characters faster.

...To be Continued as the game progresses. Thanks for reading and hope this has helped you anyway.

Rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR 8/10, 7/10 with stability figured in.


The Orion Poject is an Early Access game with a lot of heart.Imagine Halo or Destiny, or even a Zombie shooter wherethe beasts come in either wave type play, survival mode, or protect mode. It may only cost $1 at time of writing(got it on sale) but it is much fuller than many oithers that cost 20x as much. The gameplay and hitboxes are smooth and the combat is fun and fast paced(as long as everyone on the team hits R) It has several modes to play as well as being able to go offline for local co op or single player. It does have some bugs that I believe are going to be addressed. The developer is very obsessive with his creation, tweaking and fixing it on what seems to be a daily basis, to make it better. The walking and jumping feels goofy overall but doesn't distract from the gameplay. My only other complaint at this point in time is that I have a problem connecting to a host sometimes (10%) and it closes out the game completely. All in all, waaaaaaay worth $1, I would pay up to $10 for it in its current state, and with what the developer has in mind for this product, I would realistically pay $25 to $30 for a completed game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has a lot of leg room and huge potential. The development appears to have come a long way from 3 years ago.  I encountered a few issues so far in my short 5 hours of play: 1) random Unreal4 engine crashes, 2) random game drops to the main menu screen, and  3) The ability for friends to join the game through Steam seems to be a bit touchy. Although these issues only happened a few times it was enough to make it irritating. The game play itself was on Point with other big name titles. Overall I would say it is a very good start to something Wicked Awesome. Great job to the Devs for not letting this one go. I'm excited to see how this matures. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1. Friday ] As expected with any early build of a game, it crashed on me three times. Maybe tomorrow will be better day LOL Back to my NFS Most Wanted.

Day 2. Saturday ] No crashes this time, but completely freezes in the player lobby. Frankly, if this will indeed end up being another P2P online game, these issues need to be resolved. Otherwise players like me, who value their spent money a bit more than the PC purest out there, will end up feeling like we are just wasting our money. If the developers really are serious about successfully defying the gaming industry status quote, on persistent world online games, then make great effort to make sure the game actually does run stable. No Man's Sky is only a month away and already shows signs of being exactly this... stable.

Day 3. Sunday ] SUCCESS. No crashes or crippling lag with not connecting to networks. However, got in on single player only. Everything seems stable enough, with only occasional environmental glitches... such a bit of lag on generating the vegetation detail. Best to purchase now and then come back in about 2 months for a check up. Then repeat cycle if needed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR 8/10, 7/10 with stability figured in.


The Orion Poject is an Early Access game with a lot of heart.Imagine Halo or Destiny, or even a Zombie shooter wherethe beasts come in either wave type play, survival mode, or protect mode. It may only cost $1 at time of writing(got it on sale) but it is much fuller than many oithers that cost 20x as much. The gameplay and hitboxes are smooth and the combat is fun and fast paced(as long as everyone on the team hits R) It has several modes to play as well as being able to go offline for local co op or single player. It does have some bugs that I believe are going to be addressed. The developer is very obsessive with his creation, tweaking and fixing it on what seems to be a daily basis, to make it better. The walking and jumping feels goofy overall but doesn't distract from the gameplay. My only other complaint at this point in time is that I have a problem connecting to a host sometimes (10%) and it closes out the game completely. All in all, waaaaaaay worth $1, I would pay up to $10 for it in its current state, and with what the developer has in mind for this product, I would realistically pay $25 to $30 for a completed game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is one of mah favrit gams!!!!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGuardians of Orion is from the same dudes who brought you ORION: Prelude. It's a huge improved in every single way, and show how much the company has grown as a whole. If you are doubtful of getting this game due to early access, have no fear, these developers are caring, and will help guide this game, and there community to greatness. The game is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful, with stunning environments, and moving parts to each world. Though it lacks in initial content at the current moment, it offers enough, to tie you over until, the next update. You fight waves of various dinosaurs, and robots, each feeling very different in both difficulty, and attack style. The game overs 4 maps currently, a day a night option, full controller support, and 2 gamemodes. Many people have been complaining about not being able to find any players, and even though this has not personally been an issue for me, those who worry about that may feel better waiting until the game grows a bigger following. The game is still bareboned at the moment, despite monthly updates, so Early Access can feel slow at times. This isn't a game that you can sit down and play for hours, because there isn't enough you can currently do, but you can most certainly play in small hour dosages. You can switch between top down, and third person, which is ♥♥♥♥ing genius, and offers players a way to play the game the way that makes them feel comfortable. The soundtrack is stunning, and perfectly matches the vibe of the game. The game sure as hell isn't perfect though. There is minimal content, and the content added can feel more or less the same. There is no story, or missions at all, and you're stuck doing the same, protect the harvest ♥♥♥♥ for most of the game. It's very bareboned at the moment, but I would recommended getting it on sale to watch it evolve into a masterpiece of a game. In it's current state though, theres still some fun to be had with it.

Well worth the price and you will have fun playing it. Great community and game.

Early Access Review

The Orion Projekt is a well done, beautifully desingned shooter, where you can change between first person and aerial perspective. Your enemies are for the most part dinosaurs. It has a crafting system and character customization, which is rather small at the moment with two categories, but might improve over time.
The best part: The graphics, soundtracks and the large variety of characters.
The worst part: The performance of the game, which is good, but not great and hopefully soon improved.
What I look forward to: a bigger crafting and customiziation system and maybe you could divide the customization category into smaller sub-categories.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have high hopes for this game. The devs seem involved and committed to this project and it seems like we already have a good community built. The devs have a long-term plan for the game with great ideas and tons of exciting new content will be released in the next two years. The game is super cheap and really is worth it. As soon as I played it for the first time I thought to myself: Jurassic Park meets Halo! Epicness. I would recommend this game to anyone.

Pros:

- The devs are involved and committed to the game.
- Good community.
- First person mode coming soon!
- Awesome music.
- Upgrades and skill trees.
- Enemy variety.
- Ragdoll physics.
- Hats!
- Loads of exciting new content being released in the future!

Cons:

- I kind of liked the game's old name better, but oh well.
- There is a premium currency, but this might not even be an issue.
- I don't know if this is just me, but the graphics seem to need work. Forced to choose between lag or low resolution.

All in all, great game and looking forward to seeing where the devs go with it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first serious review on a game ever.

Saw game trailer.
Bought game for me and my friends.
Played it for a bit.
Loved it.
Facepalmed myself when I saw the founder thing was only until the 1st of May.
Cried deeply.
10/10

Now for a little more serious short review;
The Orion Project is a top down third person shooter developed by the same guys of Orion: Prelude, a game me and my friends played for fun quite some time ago, so I was pretty excited when I saw this game on Steam.
The game itself looks better than Prelude but lowering the graphics for me doesn't really seem to improve the fps for me.
I played only one gamemode so far and it's just the same gamemode as in Prelude. Defending a generator for as many waves as possible I had tons of fun with that. So far even though as of me writing this review I only played 0.4 hours.

Now the real question is...
Should you get this game?

Spoiler text

Short answer ;  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6vNTrdhN8k

More detailed answer : The game is so cheap and so much fun to play with friends, even if you don't like it you won't really lose alot of money anyways plus its early access so the game will improve a ton.  At least I hope so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary:	The Orion Project is a survival/objective based game. If you have played games such as Killing Floor, ORION: Dino Prelude and other titles similar to those, then this game shouldn't be  TOO  strange to you. As of now there are two game modes currently availiable and seven classes.

Don't think that just because the game is priced at a single U.S. dollar that it's of low quality. This game is very unique title worth well over one dollar even in it's current early acess state. If this game was completley polished and full of content I would be willing to spend upwards around $40.

But let's talk in detail about the game in it's current state.

The Details     Harvest
Survival
Skill Tree
Items
Classes

Harvest:
Protect your collector machine as it mines blue gold" veins from the planet. Ten waves of fighting dino's and alien creatures as this machines mines money from the ground. While doing this at certain waves a secondary objective will appear rewarding you will crafting materials
recommended:
and currency.

Survival:
Right now survival is the exact same as harvest except it never ends
hoursPlayed:
you protect the collector untill it gets destroyed or everyone dies in a single wave. The devs have future plans to make survival a lot different by removing the collecter so you only have to worry about self and team.

Skill Tree:
Think of each playable class in the game as a different hero or champion you can select to use
voteText: and each of them level up on their own; and have their own inventory; and their own unique skills; and their own weapons types yaddha yaddah.\nWell anyways the skill tree is essentially your classic skill tree found in the game Borderlands
helpfulPercent: or like Masteries in LoL. There's 3 catagorys and every time you level up you get a points to allot in each catagory. You can reset all alloted points at anytime
votesHelpful: free of charge
votesTotal:
so don't worry too much if you missclick. <I beleive the current level cap is 50>

Items:
The only thing there is to tell about items is that you can gear them towards a specific type of build prety well. My only problem is equipting different items doesn't change any visuals on the player.

Classes:
Seven different classes and many more in the making.. You will find one you like I promise.

The End:	I somewhat rushed the ending of this because I want to get back to playing this game. Freaking buy it
votesFunny: I mean what else are you going to spend a dollar on? A single stick of gum?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have very high hopes for this game. These devs have a lot of faith from me for what they're aiming to accomplish. This is one of the best looking projects I have seen for a video game. The concept may not be completely new, but I think for once it will become true. As of right now, there are only two basic game modes, a few various weapons, about 8 classes I believe, some skill trees, and about 7 maps.That's more or less the surface of this current dinosaur killing game.

Now consider: for just a dollar, you get all of that, an armor piece system mildly reminiscent of Destiny or The Division, a simple crafting system to make more gear to equip and use versus the dinosaurs. And there's more to come, as shown in the trailer.

For the entire life of Orion: Prelude, the devs listened to the players, and responded accordingly with updates and features. There have been, I believe, approximately 3 large (relative to the current size) content updates over the past 2 months and one big bug fix/tweak patch. The devs have been actively working away at this game, and to that, I raise a toast.

Seriously though, it's just a dollar. Buy it for yourself. Like it? Buy it for a friend. Spread the love. Those dollars will help keep the devs able to continuously build on this game. I'm definitely buying multiple copies to share with friends.

The game itself right now would get a solid 7/10 from me if it were a fully priced title. With it being just a dollar, and with even more content to come as well, this easily makes me hand it 9/10.

--Will update when final release comes about.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have very high hopes for this game. These devs have a lot of faith from me for what they're aiming to accomplish. This is one of the best looking projects I have seen for a video game. The concept may not be completely new, but I think for once it will become true. As of right now, there are only two basic game modes, a few various weapons, about 8 classes I believe, some skill trees, and about 7 maps.That's more or less the surface of this current dinosaur killing game.

Now consider: for just a dollar, you get all of that, an armor piece system mildly reminiscent of Destiny or The Division, a simple crafting system to make more gear to equip and use versus the dinosaurs. And there's more to come, as shown in the trailer.

For the entire life of Orion: Prelude, the devs listened to the players, and responded accordingly with updates and features. There have been, I believe, approximately 3 large (relative to the current size) content updates over the past 2 months and one big bug fix/tweak patch. The devs have been actively working away at this game, and to that, I raise a toast.

Seriously though, it's just a dollar. Buy it for yourself. Like it? Buy it for a friend. Spread the love. Those dollars will help keep the devs able to continuously build on this game. I'm definitely buying multiple copies to share with friends.

The game itself right now would get a solid 7/10 from me if it were a fully priced title. With it being just a dollar, and with even more content to come as well, this easily makes me hand it 9/10.

--Will update when final release comes about.

Early Access Review

Pros:
•it has crafting/inventory system and a shop to spend your ingame credits
•you can bug a variety of skins(hats,armor skins and more to come)

•space and dinosaurs,This developer knows how to touch a man's heart

Cons:
•the game still has many bugs and errors
•the classes don't have a bio so you don't know what that class contains
•there is no tutorial in the beginning as it is still in alpha
•there is no first person view and you can't aim with the scope

Ideas for better development of the game:
•add more weapons to equip on classes
•add a PvP against club/party/guild of players (maximum 5 pvpv players)
•Add an animation in the main menu of the game
•and of course,the ability to travel to planets(many people would love this)
•more game modes or open world

This game,although in alpha version,is worth paying for.And in time you'll see
A game which was worth paying for.I hope the developers keep up the good
Work.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welp. Here it is. My first review ever.

Guardians of Orion is an intense, action-focused tower defense with dinosaurs and mechs, of which make the game all the more fun in the harder difficulties when you get to see varieties of them.

PROS:
+AWESOME graphics with the Unreal Engine
+Interesting enemies and storyline (which you can see when you first open the game if you let it sit for a few minutes)
+Unique classes with their own special abilities
+Detailed, unique enviornments
+Cool (although limited) character customization
+Pay OR Play system
+Community seems friendly at the moment

CONS:
-The leveling system. A little complicated. (Not 110% sure how it works yet, but I think I have an idea)
-The reward system. Playing a harder diffculty offers the same rewards as the lower difficulties, just more of them
-The robotic enemies. The dinosaur AI is fine, but the robotic enemies seem a little lackluster in their combat abilities and could be tweaked a little in later updates.
-The T-REX. (JEEZ!)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is good.
The visuals are great, and the enemies are interesting. The actual game mechanics are fun aswell.

let me talk about the bad things, but rest assured the only bad things are cosmetic issues that I would like to be fixed:
- I would like to see the UI/HUD vastly improved, at the moment it looks far too simplistic, with many items on screen having a simple slightly opaque border. this goes for the health bars, and the main menu. It all looks too plain.
- I understand recycling sounds is easy to do, but I think we can all agree that the same annoying sound of the dinos chewing on the ship is infuriating. Please add differing noises and sounds for things e.g. footsteps, biting. Maybe even add a crunchy noise when you land after using your jetpack

The only technical issue I can fault is the lack of servers outside of the US. I live in Britain though, and have felt no lag so maybe the issue isn't that big. Though I'm sure people in Europe may at points wish for Europe servers.

Early Access Review

MAIN REVIEW:
This game is a great top down shooter with dinosaurs which builds off its older brother Orion Prelude. It has guardians which you pick from to play with and its easily playable offline and an additional online.
The game is good at this stage and is getting a brighter future ahead as the devs explain.

BELOW SOME CONFESSIONS AND THINGS TO KEEPS FOR THE DEVS!
Now I plan to play more of this game but hear me out Devs!!!!!!

So......
PLEASE FIX/REMOVE ONLINE PLAY! Alrighty it works don't worry its fine. I mean for Australian servers so.  THANK YOU!

PLEASE FIX UI ELEMENT! The controller buttons appearing everywhere should be a option that can be turned off.

PLEASE FIX UI ELEMENT FOR OFFLINE. The reliance on local play is too big offline, make the game settings bigger.

PLEASE CREATE MORE DIVERSE MAPS? Maybe more ruins or a city or more hills and less flat land like Orion Prelude???

PLEASE REVAMP THE ART FOR THE GUARDIANS! Make them the same art and not from previous game.  THANK YOU!

TRY TO PLEASE ADD IN FIRST PERSON! I know, I know but make it an option.  NEVERMIND!

MAKE MORE GAMEMODES FAST! Somethings need another twist. I don't know, maybe a campaign?

SOME COLLISIONS BETWEEN HARVESTER AND DINOSAURS! Really ruins the game when you see a dinosaur go through the harvester when your trying to repair it.

PLEASE KEEP THE BROKEN ELEMENTS WHEN YOUR DAMAGED. Cracked screen, keep.

Yeah, MORE VARIETY IN GAMEPLAY. As cheesy as this sounds, it needs more. Offline I couldn't find more than 2 gamemodes and thats it. I can guess it gets boring after a while but its ok with Survival and Harvester.

REMOVE THE LOW GRAPHICS. They look terrible and have no need to be here. Meduim should be low and so on. When comapring all of them the only that stands out is low and the others only have texture differences and a frame rate difference.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the games I definitely love to play for hours but something is up with the system requirements. My pc is definitely in the minimum requirement, but is that how bad the minimum requirement looks? Everything looks really bad on Low settings. I know how its supposed to look really beautiful with proper pc build, but good god if you have a pc that falls into the minimum requirement of this game, you should probably reconsider.

All in all, I love this game, I would love it even more if the minimum requirement actually represents the reality of running this game on such system, because at this point its almost like a false hope. I know its an early access game, but I think this is something that the devs might probably want to work on; with the minimum requirement all I got is 20 Fps and everything is nothing but blurs.

And before someone goes, Hey man its just your potato that sucks balls

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is hard for me to stay neutral when devs are as nice as these guys.

When their first game started as a desaster they did not try to shut down bad reviews or try to semi-abandon it with minimalistic patches. No, they handled the situation as professional and enthusiastic as possible. And i thank them for keeping my faith with indie-development.

There first game later became a success and i really recommend it. They also said it will get more content even though this one here is their main focus now. Which also speaks for them being awesome and generous people.

For the game itself: I like teamplay, loot and crushing waves in a fun manner. And the more the development gets forward the more content and the deeper it will become.

So what is not to like?

Maybe a few lagspikes, a bit stuttering. But nothing gamebreaking. At least not for me.

TL;DR: I love you, devs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't really write reviews normally, games are a subjective thing and everyone's taste are different but wow.  This game if played with a group is so much fun.  I don't wanna see a developer that really put something interesting together not get rewarded for that.  At two dollars this really is the most fun you can have and the thing is if they really do come through with some of the other stuff they are proposing I think the game can only get more feature rich which is a good thing.

The negatives are simply that the game right now doesn't have zillions of players and if they don't get players then the game won't be the fun it could be.  There is solo play but its dull in comparison to playing a mix of classes together.  The other thing right now is the itemization is a bit confusing level wise but I hear thats being addressed.  It is also early access so not all the content is in place and really right now I feel like the main menu needs a class tab where you can tweak your characters between rounds, as is you need to enter a game to make changes it seems.

I recommend it the mechanic of switching between overhead view and third person really is cool.  I know many were mad they didn't go with the first person view like Orion but the switching between third person and overhead really is seemless and works well for this type of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After trying to give Orion: Prelude a chance time and time again, I thought I made a mistake buying this game. I don't think I did.
This game is pretty good, it does need some work though. I would really like some sort of laser sight to see what you are aiming at easier in the top-down view. I also think the crafting and skills should be able to be acsessed outside of an actual match, but the devs probably have a reason for this. This game reminds me of a mixture between Killing Floor, Halo, an old game called SAS: Zombie Assault, but with dinosaurs. It is rather easy to solo, but you don't get as many chances to get good loot, so I would probably reccomend playing with a group. It being $0.99 is also pretty nice. ^_^

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Coming from Orion Prelude I thought I had a pretty good idea what I was in for. A fun shooter without much meat around it, but good enough to keep me going for a few hours.
Guardians of Orion (EDIT: Now The Orion Project) is not that. It's so much more.
Play it top-down or in 3rd person. Play with friend, play alone. Slaughter (now survive) or survive (now harvest). Play with a controller or with kb and mouse.
In my own experience I've found the controller to be great fun in top-down action and a single survival game can often last up to three hours.

GOO (EDIT: Now PO :) ) is a great twin-stick shooter with a very (very) active dev that listens and responds (even to the tiniest things). Since the day I purchased it when I first saw it appear on Steam to now I've already seen incredible changes. Can't wait to see more.

Being a fan of Orion Prelude I have a lot of faith in this game and will support it all the way. The devs have a real passion for what they're doing here and with big plans.
I didn't buy this game on $1 sale like many others, I paid the full price and it's been completely worth it. When it did go on $1 sale though I bought a bunch of copies and gifted them to friends, because they need to play this.

So, as the game is right now, is it worth buying? You bet. It's immensely fun with a leveling system that feels like you're working hard to earn XP but somehow never feels like a grind. It just has the right balance.

The weapons are fun and from what I've seen seem quite balanced. The classes are different enough to give each player something that suits their own style. Come the patch on 25 April 2016 they added some more impressive content like character customisation and complete level overhauls.
I've read a few people had optimisation issues, but honestly I'm not sure how. I've got a three year-old pc and it runs on mine like it does in the trailer. They're not lying.

Keep up the good work devs...and people of Steam, give this one a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR; Basics are kill dinos to get gold, upgrade your character to kill dinos easier. Solid topdown or third person shooter, four player or single player dino killin fun for just about any newish pc or modern laptop. The object of the game is to protect your harvester by killing dinos and upgrading your hero with the blue gold. There are multiple heros and guns and dinos and levels or maps. Each hero has at least one unique ability, There is so much planned for this game that I cannot express it in an TLDR.

This game is a mix between a very accessible topdown twin stick dino shooter and a very solid TPV/FPV dino shooter. With many planned features or modules in the works. I would expect to have bugs and small issues until most of the planned features of The Orion Project universe are added. Then the process of optimization begins. This game is worth ten dollars right now as is but for a short time you can get it for one dollar!

Some planned features
Space based city with housing.
Planets.
Your own space ship.
Mechs, just like Orion prelude but this time with at least three types.
Hoardes of dinos!!!!!! (At least ten so far)
Guns. (implemented)
Class based heros, female and male.(implemented)
Grenades (implemented)
Vehicles.
Open world/universe.
Trek store (where all things can be purchased with money earned in game or real money if you desire)

I like this game because its innovative, has a roadmap, sticks to it goals like superglue, and listens to the gamers.. wait that might be the developers I'm talking about.

Get dropped off, protect an excavator or whatever it is, kill a bunch of dinosaurs, rinse and repeat only on 3 other levels over and over. That's the game.

I would say at most $8-$10 max and thats being generous. I think the biggest let down for this game was the support from the devs. I think the ocmmunity spent more time trying to solve this issue then they did.

Originally posted by David James:Originally posted by Mayate:Take the free helmet promotion for example. The topic is listed under general discussion rather than as a sticky under a Event/Promotion thread. After a few days and countless posts later you wouldn't even know there was even such a promotion unless you heard it in game.

I don't think the majority of gamers on steam would actively read the discussion forums on a new game much less during a free to play weekend.

It does seem rather sore of them to say no you missed the cutoff, you were supposed to log in before the deadline even if you bought the game during the event. I would think rather than to deny buyers that bought the game prior to the deadline their status; they should allow them their founder status due to a small technicality to promote their player base.
It's a posted discussions, it's an advertised news announcement and it's in the beginning of nearly every trailer we've made since announcing it.

Your Events/Promotion suggestion is a good idea and would be better suited for the suggestions thread, but acting like we talk about it one and done is crap.

All that being said, a minimal and fractional number of the gaming population visits forums or interacts on anything deeper than playing the actual game.  Most people never watch the trailers/videos, check the news or read the forums so it affects very few to begin with/
Replied to a general discussion thread Founder Status" in favor of granting a group of people that paid for the game during an event period their founder status and benefits
date:
but failed to create an account prior to the deadline period. Gave an example of how certain promotions were not being advertised well and how it can be fixed rather easily. Tried to hint that a happy playbase promotes more advertising by way of "word of mouth" through existing members. That in return would increase playbase and the possiblity of increased microtransactions which is the path this developer is taking the game through.

However the developer replied in accusation and complete defense. That was my first and only post on the orion project discussion forum. I understand some developers are passionate about their work but a tactless developer can be detrimental to their products and how the gaming base and community grows. That's why companies as well as celebrities hire public relation firms to oversee their customer departments and twitter accounts. (Viewers feel free to read more of his responses on the orion project discussion forums and see for yourself*) I understand that its taxing to deal with certain individuals on a giving basis but its a completely different matter when you're representing something. I didn't my comment was attacking anyone but if I were you should still have been the bigger man. That's the position you're suppose to assume so that others will support you no matter how outrageously demanding or rather reasonable players can be.

The orion project is a decent short term time waster. Still early with the usual "early access" bugs and low playerbase. Teamwork is going to be key. Unfortunately due to the developer's general nature and his future plans for the game I will not be playing any further. I have a feeling he'll reply to this and defend his statements. I'll leave it as is and move on.

The Orion Project
Game Rating 4/10

bugs so far:
- players stuck in terrain
- incorrect loadout going into map
- out of bounds respawn
- large dinos can be trapped in terrain permanently
- infinite ammuntion bug present without the use of legendary augment (can be manipulated)
- no hud bug during
- drop pod stays on the ground for the entire duration of match

comments:
- lower body in first person mode looks sluggish
recommended:
movement does not look realistic when paired with upper body
- multiple slow time phases interrupts the momentum of gaming (General mixed feelings on forum)
- drops are not highlighted in minimap (creating a pet that picks up loot will not solve this problem*)
- needs an option to display a large map of the environment while ingame (can solve drop highlight problem and help navigate terrain to find mobs during redikculous chest wave*)
- keyboard bindings are not optimally placed. Players should move their Ability/blink/melee to their extra mouse buttons and grenade to Q if possible."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI sort of enjoyed the previous game, Orion: Prelude, so I hoped that this would be better than the last one. The trailer certainly looked nice, but when the game is launched, it totally seizes up. Apparently, it recognizes my craptop as a high-end computer, as the visual settings were automatically on super high. Even when I set them to low, the game had constant skips in it. The audio was constantly bugging; even selecting things in the menus was glitchy. The last game was like this too, but I guess development has been abandoned on that. I couldn't even get to play the main game, but walking around was okay. It's sort of like a MOBA or something. I readied up and the game crashed. Fix the bugs and we'll be good. But for now, I'm not too fond of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Waiting simulator 2016

Honestly, I expected better from this game. This game gets repetitive and boring very fast. Spent 30 mins on it and they were the most boring 30 mins I had this week. There is a lack of action. Don't even bother with solo, you will get bored in first 5 minutes. When playing online with 3 other players, you get like 15 seconds of action and then you wait for almost a minute for next wave of dinos. There is nothing to do when waiting except running around and doing nothing. And it goes in a loop like this. Probably the same applies when playing with friends. Some guns (like shotgun) are too OP. Spoke with other players in team chat, they agreed with everything I just wrote. Can't think of any good aspects of this game. 3 words: Repetitive, boring, confusing. Can't recommend this game to anyone.

10/10 would buy waiting simulator again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGame is not optimized at all to play in third person since people get massive fps lag (at least on older computers like mine). On lowest settings  (literally pixel graphics) with 6gb ram and 2gb video card i had like max 12-15fps in third person. And still there's stuff like disconnect issues resulting in your character lvl rollback etc. There are also bugs. I dont mind ping being high since it doesnt affect the gameplay much. However, I checked their patchnotes, it's ok that they focus on releasing content like 2 new classes, but come on, first of all at least make the game playable without fps lag, disconnects and other bugs, and then focus on contents. And yes the content is kinda limited too - only like 4 maps, limited skills and guns to each class makes this game boring very quickly. It's ok that you introduce inventory system and crafting, and that you look in the future to make a first person mode and introduce more classes, but for now this game is not worth its price (unless you buy it on sale for like 2-3 euros like i did). Im not even discussing that this game is almost 4 months old and there are less than 700 reviews (not enough promotion done), and online at the very best you gonna find like 5-6 rooms hosted and like 20-30 people playing. I know it's early access and the game looks promising, but the devs are obviously doing something wrong, or not doing good enough.

I was a little iffy about it being a top down shooter but I still have fun playing this game both pre and post early access release.

Even as a top down shooter you can still jetpack on top of terrain and pick off dinosaur's and now robots (awesome addition!) and still get destroy by a T-Rex hurling a giant boulder at you.

After hearing rumors about adding an FPS mod I really hope more people pick the game up, play with a group of friends, and support a great team who have stayed true to their work and loyal to their fans to make this a reality and become an FPS like ORION: Prelude was.

10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGuardians of Orion has an impressive list of features, certainly, but I can't really name any of them that work all that well.  Technically, the game runs, you can shoot dinosaurs, pick up loot, play co-op, spend skill points and all that.  It just isn't fun.  The guns are weightless and pretty boring to use, the dinosaurs aren't particularly interesting or well-animated, the loot system is pure stat-boosts, so it's not particularly interesting, and the skill trees are just stat boosts as well, meaning what you get at the beginning is what you have at the end, too.  If the game were any fun to play, the lack of any meaningful change in gameplay might be fine, but this is just boring.  Don't waste your time or money on this when there are so many better options out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll update this as it goes through Early Access.

I hopped into the game for the first time to give it a try and played a couple of different classes. It's a little dull at the moment because of the current lack of playerbase but that should pick up as the game develops and I hope it does pick up because this is the sort of game that will hopefully be easy to play in a relaxed fashion with friends and online players alike.

The current price tag is probably only worth paying for if you're keen to support the devs and want to contribute to the Early Access development because at the moment, there's not a huge amount here. There's a solid foundation including 4 classes with different weapons, a couple of game modes, nice graphics and lovely music. I was surprised to find the third person gameplay handling quite well as I was a bit skeptical about that and overall all the controls are fine, no issues there.

So the only thing I can see lacking so far really is content and playerbase, which will come in time. I plan to keep checking up on the game regularly to test out new content and I'm glad to see the devs aiming for monthly updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Will update as I continue to play - current impressions based on 1.5 hours of play.

What fun! Online with friends is clearly the best way to play, but if you find yourself gunning solo like myself, you won't be disappointed. Fun character skill tree mixed with twin-stick gunning goodness makes for a fun romp. Jetpack gameplay adds some (very limited) verticality that adds to the overall experience. Great sci-fi feel to the game.

Currently this game feels like a good way to kill 30 or 45 minutes in its current early access state. Felt satisfied with my $10 purchase on this alone.

EDIT: The third person mode recently went live. It's not my favorite thing on earth (video below, shameless plug), but it proves that the dev is constantly listening to community feedback and responding quickly with updates that the community wants. This is the sign of a great dev, devoted to his craft.

https://youtu.be/DuPiNBsqneg

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far into the game, I have to say that its in a very poor condition, the AI not being really responsive with lots of bugs (especially when the assault guardians land on top of higher geometry, explains how we got past the T-Rex on hard), the game itself is kinda laggy, not really responsive in controls, the gunplay feels pretty poor, not much in terms of content and gamemodes, basically at the very moment, the game is simply a grindfest with the base game being pretty poor in optimization and gameplay value. And at very first sight of actual gameplay, I was slightly disappointed to have realized its a top down shooter, not really my cup of tea, but after learning about the F1 button being the perspective switch, I might have decided to give it a better chance. That however doesn't help the fact just how clunky the controls are and how lame the gunplay is all in all.

But however, this doesn't really stop me from believing that the developers behind the game will do everything in their power to provide the best experience possible, fixing glitches, bugs, improving the AI (or at least I hope they manage that). This may sound oddly forgiving, I know, but I trust that these developers will do whatever they can, judging from the amount of people who have told that they make frequent updates to the game with numerous fixes and such. Plus, considering this is another project from the same studio which have got quite the praise of their sci-fi dino shooters, I'd much prefer to keep myself on the optimistic side believing the devs will actually fulfill their promises of an open world dino shooter thing-of-a-jig (which I myself am really hoping to see soon), hence why I will be giving this a thumbs up, just to keep the spirit strong.

But seriously guys, fix your AI, and your bugs, and give us maybe less clunky controls and maybe more feeling to the guns, otherwise its as I already said will feel just completely lame.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a very fun game especially if you play it with friend

Pros
- The Dev are nice (They listen and active with the community)
- Beautiful Graphics
- Multiple Classes (and there still will be more)
- You can choose to play it in TPS or Top Down (There also will be FPS)
- Flamethrower (it's always fun to burn things right?)
- Different kind of dinosaur
- Bosses
- The music is good

Cons
- Could be repetitive so easily (especially if you play without friend)
- Only 2 game modes (for now)
- Only 2 servers US and EU
- Some things in the game could be confusing (like Crafting and the Inventory)

8/10

Note
The dev are having a hard time because the game aren't selling as well as they hoped, and the dev will likely to move on to their next project and discontinued this game (i wish they will keep updating it or something though, cus this game has a lot of potential)
if you purchase and play this game before May 1 2016, you will become a founder
Founders will get
- All 10 Guardians (Non-Founders will only get 3 and have to pay to get the rest)
- 20,000 Store Credits
- Founder Icon
- Gold Armor Skin
- Gold Weapon Skin
BUT, the dev said if this game sold exponentially well they will take another look at it and support the game again
So if you seen this review and haven't purchase the game yet, PLEASE purchase it or if you already have, you can purchase it as a gift for your friends (as i told you, it's more fun with friends)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Guardians of Orion is a solid sci-fi action game. It is played in a top-down perspective, and so far has been very enjoyable. It is early access, so there are improvements to be made, and obviously more content is to be added at a specified date, but this is fine as the devs have set a schedule for releases. So far as of Dec 2015, the game is fairly fluid, and runs well on my mid-range PC. There are 3 classes, assault, recon and support, with their respective skill trees and preset loadouts. Assault has a full-auto rifle and a pistol, and has a jetpack. Recon has a 3-round SMG and a auto pistol, and can cloak. Support has a shotgun and a heavy pistol, and has a drop-shield-style ability capable of healing all allies in its radius. Enemies are fairly varied, and range from tiny dinosaurs that are hard to hit, to rolling robot orbs that chuck grenades at you. Game is enjoyable, and has a lot of potential to expand into a really great game.

8.5/10, for current build

EDIT: The january update has added a lot of new content to the game, including a third-person mode and a new class. We have been promised a new guardian every month, and so this game has significantly improved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially I was a little disappointed with the game, which I mainly bought after seeing how well the developer's previous game was handled. And whilst there still needs to be more variety to the gameplay and depth to the classes, what really stands out is the development. Lots has been changed, added and made better in the short period I've owned it, and what's to come sounds even more exciting.

I'd definitely pick this game up while you can still get founders status (before May 2016) and if you do so during the upcoming steam free play event you can try it and then buy it and get founders status for only a dollar (later the game will be a dollar but you won't get all the perks). If you're on the fence I'd strongly suggest reading the community posts about what's upcoming in the game (like an open world in v1.6) sounds pretty rad to me, I didn't get it for as cheap as a dollar and I'm very happy that I picked it up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, this is gonna be a decently long review.. I've always been a HUGE fan of the Sci-Fi/RPG genre, and i've never found any game that reached my desires.. but I found this game a few months back, and I was watching it, but then about 2 months ago (as of April 26, 2016) I saw that they started to change the game completely.. I loved it, and I just watched it change, and change into a better game.. So, it went on sale 2 days ago (as of April 25, 2016) and I bought it for 1$, I had my friend try and and I bought him the game too, so I hope that this game reaches it's full potential, and i'll always support the devs...

GAMEPLAY:
Alright, the gameplay is hands-down awesome, I mean.. who doesn't want to shoot robots/dinos in a futuristic Sci-Fi scene, and the fact that it's SO EASY to make a server with you and your friends amazes me, but I give the gameplay 9.1/10 because there are still some bugs that can be made.

SOUNDTRACK/AUDIO:
Okay, I LOVE this soundtrack.. In the space hub, it's so calm and relaxing, I could just listen to it all day.. and the music hypes you up when you play in-game, because it's got a rock feeling to it, but it's not rock/heavy metal.. I just don't know how to explain how beautiful the sound track(s) are. I give it a 10/10.

COMMUNITY:
This is probably the best community out there, because I ALWAYS see new players, and they ask stuff like How do I play?" or "Where do I go?" and everyone always answers so nicely. 10/10.

PLAYER ROLES:
Alright
date: they could use a bit of nerfing for classes such as the Marksman because his fire rate is VERY slow to me
recommended:
but overall they're very well set up. 8.6/10.

SKILL TREE/SKILLS:
Okay

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game seems really fun!


Me and my friends originally bought prelude, and we didn't really like it. The mechanics seemed really wonky and it didn't work very well, so we had a good laugh.

In guardians, they reinvented the formula, adding a wave type system with items, crafting, and augments, and this game is still isn't even done!
The amount of content is low, yes. With only 5 guardians (my favorite being support) and 4 maps (<3 outback), there isn't that much to offer if you're looking at the surface, but this game has some pretty cool mechanics that make it replayable.
I'll probably play this for a while, and once it's stopped offering content, I'll come back every update, and probably put in a lot more time when it officially releases.
Otherwise, I really enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: So the game is very playable now and I thought I would update it--even what's here now is stable, and a good amount of content: lots of characters, a crafting system, loot drops, and bunch of different dinosaurs trying to eat you and your robot. The third person works well, although I am still excited to see the first person module in practice. So worth the price, even in its current incomplete state.

Get it now before Founder status goes away!

I don't do early access games as a rule because a lot of devs are pretty untrustworthy, and it's a lot easier to have good ideas and sell that to rubes than it is to make a thing that does what they actually want. That said, these guys have really won me over-- Prelude is a lot of fun, pretty much distilling what makes a wave defense game a good time and leaving everything else out, which is fine by me.

So, when I saw the push these devs were making so that they could stay working on this game, I broke my own rule for the dollar buy-in price. I know they'll see it through. Plus, even just looking through these reviews you can see people having their suggestions implemented, and the devs are keeping the updates coming, and have some seriously good stuff coming down the pipeline-- I can't wait for the First Person Module, for example. That alone would be worth the cost of the game, as the scenery is so pretty and the dinosaurs look so good, is seems like a shame to be in third person, away from the action.

Anyway, I've got high hopes and real faith that these guys will pull something out of this that's worth a lot more than the dollar I threw in when they needed it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have bought into many alpha staged games, such as Overgrowth...
Every single one of them after getting your money just bounce and have a nice comfy life... BUT THIS DEVELEPER SEEMS PROMISING!

Honestly, the game was a top down shooter and within a month they add 3rd person...  They only charge $1, and seem to be extremely promising on taking this game beyond Planet Side 2 scale, and beyond Battle Fields player size...

The initial way to get in a game and access your items is not very user friendly, but after you learn it. It is very nicely set up.



GAMEPLAY!
Pro's: The game has nice graphics and you can customize your playstyle by swapping to an emersize 3rd person, to top down at any time in the game.
Very nice AI which at easy dificulties are competitive, and at higher difficulties eat your lunch like your a cupcake.
This game has an amazing sound track for being in Alpha!
Nice sounds with the guns and the objectives are straight forward.
Every person gets their own loot, so there is no loot stealing and crying about so-so got this and do not need it.
The diverse classes let your customize your play style while still allowing every player to be viable.

Con's: The game does not seem to last as long as I would like. I see many people on wave 28 or above, and I join a game on wave 3 and it's victory by wave 8...
Hard to learn gearing system...
Hard to learn crafting system...

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's still Early Access but TREK already put it for 1 buck so there was no way I wouldn't get it. From what I played I can see great potential. The combat feels better than Orion:Prelude and the different cameras are satisfying to shoot from. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is literally the BEST $2 USD I've ever spent! Sure it's Early Access right now and a lot needs to be done but I feel that this will be my favorite top down shooter (besides HellDivers). This game looks really good right now in Third-Person perpective in relation to the fact that this is a Top-down shooter. Gameplay is smooth but a bit lackluster right now as there is no limited ammo so you don't really need to use the pistol at all. I'm sure limited ammo will be implemented before the game goes live. Hopefully the shop buildings from Prelude will make it into the game as well. There's only two game modes right now and they play pretty much the same. There's also only two difficulties that I had access to anyway which is easy and normal and normal was pretty easy so I imagine easy is a walk in the park. I haven't really touched the skill trees or crafting system so I can't comment on those yet. Trek Industries and Spiral, Keep up the amazing work on this title.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn my opinion, this game gets a solid 8/10 rating from me, it's nearly there. I mean, you run around shooting dinosaurs and robots, how could it be bad? The gameplay is fun and fast paced, the engine the game runs on works smoothly and the differnt ways to play and upgrades you can choose keep the game fresh. There are few things I think that could be changed or added to make the game better which are: The break time in between each wave is too long, shorten it from 1 minute to 15-20 seconds so everyone has to time their special skills better and use time healing better so you can get everyone to full health before the next wave comes. Also, maybe take away the heal guns ability to heal the user, make it so it can replenish shields by right clicking, but make it so you can't heal yourself so more teamplay is required. You might want to keep the self heal in solo mode however. And finally, (i know the game is still in development) just add a storyline, the possiblity for a solo campaign is a good one. That's all I have to say, hope the devs notice this so yeah. That's it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A little diffient from Orion: Prelude but still good.

Basically this is a top-down shooter, but actually it can change to third-person view very well, and the developer promise to add first-person view in the future, so this game will be a three in one awesome game!

(Notice: in game you can press F1 to change view)

Use Unreal 4 engine so look very good for a $1 game, but you may need a good system to run it smoothly. There are a little bug, but don't worry, because the developer will fix it very soon, just report in the discussion area!

Gameplay is good, simple defend mode like the Killing Floor, but have more RPG element, you can earn exp for kill dino and level up, assign skill point, loot equipment and material to become stronger!

For now the game have just five map, seem a little lacking, but the developer will add more.

Many kind of cute dinosaurs, and developer promise add more in the future.

This game is on early access, and just $1 cheap, so don't be too harsh on him, but wait a few time patiently, it will be a great game. Good Job! David! You are so good! Thank you for your hard work all the time!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cannot recommend this at it's current state. This is definitely not the 'ultimate space adventure and combat video game for PC'. There's no open world or persistant universe, no galaxy to travel either. Not yet anyways.

There's no tutorial or any sort of introduction whatsoever.
The game seems to be made for people with gamepads, or at least that's my first impression.
You see a gamepad control layout every time you load a map.
I don't even have a gamepad and I don't see why I'd want to use it for a game like this. Why shove it in my face?

Gameplay is boring as hell. You can either shoot dinosaurs and robots, or NOT shoot dinosaurs and robots.

The class system and character progression remind me too much of Firefall. Firefall was silly, imho (don't even get me started).

In Firefall you have several battleframes (character classes) which you have to level up separately, and they're very limited in what they can do. That's a lot of grind. Why not make it so your character and his profession evolve independant from each other or something?

Will wait for further updates. I kinda want this game to accomplish what Firefall could not.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt $1 sure, it's something you can get an hour out of. It's a nice looking game I guess. I had beef with Prelude but me and a few buds had some good fun out of it, this game doesn't have any of the positives of Prelude. It's made for the top-down view and you can tell. Shooting isn't as good, movement isn't, obviously no vehicles in current state. Game isn't much of a game in it's current shape, especially the terrible item/crafting system that was just poorly done. Optimization is bad, lots of sound loops, lots of stugger and lag on a rig that can max Far Cry 4 and Fallout 4, even when I lower settings on this game it just glitches out. Had to restart the game 4 times before it would finally log in online, lots of people report this problem. Overall a technical nightmare in current form. What will TOP be like in a year? Not sure, maybe good. That's the main reason I put $1 down on this game, evntually it might be alright. $1 isn't much of a risk.

At this time I cannot recommend this game to you. I'm excusing the bugs and frame rate because that is expected in Early Access and though they are there this is not what affected me most. The game has no life in it right now, it's very bare bones and the bones aren't much fun. The game feels empty, like it has no heart. Try checking back later or pick the game up when its on sale. Maybe things will change.  It's a good concept and I hope to see it improve because it could be really fun. This is all my opinion and if things change so will this review."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now since this game is going for something really big in the future doesnt mean it can escape the present.
I'm only making this review as a first impressions type of thing. il lget to pros and cons after my suggestions for the game.
1st: make video options a bit more advanced I goto the settings I get Super high" it has a fair amount of settings to start with but still needs improvment
2nd: Sounds options no matter what I did the UI made a huge noise everytime I put my cursor on them and grenades blow out my ears. (this is most likely a pety complaint but still being able to hear is nice!)
3rd: movement is still only ment for top-down 3rd person feels too constricted. (The rol lis terrible no point of using it too delayed)
4th: Better UI structure overall (honestly game's ui looks like a rip of any menu)
5th: This is a pet-peeve but make the cross-hair not your menu cursor it gets lost in the colour.
6th: Explanation of things going on I looked at the videos and played the game and I was strait confused.
7th: Game is a very basic shooter (Though I expect gunplay and all that too be so much better as it currently is)
8th: Whats up with the controller only controls when the game loads either have both keyboard/mosue and controller or just get rid of it!
9th: I have no clue what I'm doing since there is just too much put to you without explanation some tool-tips would be nice

Pros:
Game Functions for me
No FPS drops (I use 980ti idk about other cards)
game has a ton going for it

Cons:
Gun play is boring to say the least
everything is way too basic to make sence of things
Objectives are either defend thing or go do a time limit thing (make those shorter honestly you can beat them in less than five mins)
graphic options are limited I put everything maxed and the game looks like a blur
sounds are off abit
Game UI is bad and basic looks like a mobile port for the buttons
game is just very basic overall (there are crafting
recommended:
and equips)
Crafting because thats what the cool games are doing (not saying it's bad but is felt forced in for no reason)
Currently desc/videos/pictures lie about how the game's current status is.

My finalish thouights on the game:
It's MEH it's not the worst thing I played nor is it the best they are promissing something huge and even making it and a sweet 90% discount but... the game in it's current state feels like a arcade game pop a quarter in play with 3 lives stop playing. NOW what makes me question is Why change this game? it doesnt seem logical to me just change a top-down shooter to this now propsed awesome space sifi game that is ment to be crazy. It's feels like too much to belive for me.
Now do I doubt they will make a flop again  Yes oh god YES  well actually I think they might havea chance to make something great but they just gotta not have another flop.

Now for my current rating of the game: 2.3/5 needs huge amount of work but it is a game and it is playable

I just can't suggest you get it in it's current state (my review will change as the game evolves)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I payed a dollar for this game and i still feel like the 20 five cent candies from the corner store would have provided me more dinosaur related entertainement.


This isn't orion. This is a failed diablo clone. I get that it's early access but it feels more like a flash game then a game you spend money on. It shouldn't even be called Orion because it has only one thing in common with orion. It has dinosaurs.
In this game your in an overhed view as opposed to the classic first person of orion. In the original orion you would go in teams of four against hordes of dinosaurs trying to destroy your generator or something and it was fun. You could feel the stuggle at times, you could feel the role each of the classes played and you felt like you were hunting dinosaurs. It mixed the fun of dinosaurs with the combat of something like halo or left 4 dead.

But in this game your in a team of 4 in an endless escort mission. You know those really annoying mission from games where you escort the annoying character that serves little to no purpose and just constantly dies resulting in a game over. Thats this game. So to go into detail remember how in orion you were in a constant struggle and all the classes served a purpose. In this game if you choose the assault class you win. Literally you can stand in one spot and as long as you point the gun in the right direction no matter the dinosaur it dies( excluding the t-rex) yeah real exciting. It's like stomping on ants except you have to shoot the ant's with a machine gun except way less cool and fun. Anyways so you go further in the game and youll notice that after 1-2 hits your screen starts cracking up and the first thing that pops into your head is, I CANT SEE ♥♥♥♥! because you literally cannot see unless your constantly moving your head. Not only is this annoying but it also makes no sense. This is a third person game so why are there first person screen effects. So anyways as you go on you finally get a new mission and the title Hunt the t-rex" or something like that so you think to yourself oh hey that actually sounds cool so you run up to it start shooting it and realize you do almost nothing to it. Then it throws an undodgeable rock at you and you instantly die. Now the respawn time is a problem in itself. if you get injured you have to wait 40 seconds before you bleed out which is good for multiplayer but if your on single player its a waste of time there needs to be a way to suicide because the dino's dont attack you in that state. Then once you die you have to wait another 40 seconds before you respawn. Then when you respawn you have to sit through a 10 second tease of almost orion gameplay. Then you try the t rex again realize you still cant hurt him wait another 2 minutes switch your class not do anything to him and give up.

In conclusion this game feels empty and has a long way to go before it can compete with my dino candies and if your looking for a new orion game go to the corner store and spend your ten bucks on some dino candies and those little sponge dinosaurs that soak up the water and get bigger."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: You can totally go into third-person. Doesn't change the very limited mechanics, but hey, take what you can get, I guess.
So, firstly, I think this should've been a first or third person shooter. A wave and class based shooter with strong team elements would have been way more interesting than yet another bird's eye twin stick.
To elaborate, there is a class with a jetpack. Because of the viewpoint, it's completely useless unless you're facing a boss that can actually catch up to you.
Speaking of bosses, most of them straight up cannot hit you. If you backpedal, they catch up to you, but the wind up takes too long, so you're completely safe. The only actual threats are normal enemies that don't suffer from this problem, and when bosses go for the harvester in a certain gamemode.
As far as I know, all classes have a regeneration gun that has no cooldown or charge. At any time, you can just whip it out, heal completely, heal the harvester, and lose nothing.
Adding to this problem, the AI will sometimes just run away or go for the harvester alone, completely ignoring you. This isn't a problem, unless it's a boss that takes a ton of damage while it hits the harvester for a ton of damage. So, either you lose everything in one shot, or absolutely nothing mattered.
Music is either fine or terrible. It's either Linkin Park/Doom or Mirror's Edge. How it's implemented is also terrible. At the end of a round, the music just cuts to the Mirror's Edge track. It's jarring going from edgy butt-rock to soft pianos with a sudden cut in the middle.
In general, it's pretty boring. You get attacked by dinosaurs, but it's just some creature with no interesting combat elements. There are also humanoids who have guns, and they have mechs that have blade things, but neither of those shake anything up.

TL:DR Should've been a different perspective, very dull, bad enemy movesets, dumb AI, unbalanced both ways seemingly at random, music isn't great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first Orion game I have actually played and I must say, I'm impressed.

The graphics are very nice, reminds me of the Trine series. It's bright and vibrant and fits the themes of the levels very well. On that note, the level design is also great too. It's easy to move around and isn't too inconvienient to get to and from the side objectives and the harvester. The soundtrack is great and really gets the blood pumping as you destory waves of dinosaurs and robots. The controls are also very easy to learn (I played with a controller).

The multiplayer connection is also very stable and I had no connection problems, which is quite rare considering I live in Australia. The game is also well optimised, had no problems with fps either.

All in all this is a very nice game to play solo or online with some buddies, with that good ol' Orion feel.

https://youtu.be/l3p3LcVA8UI

reviewText:
Early Access Review

welp this is my first shot at an actual review so here it goes.

the good:
-isometric view is a pretty interesting take on the horde survival genre(with some side missions)
-unlike the previous game(orion:prelude, which gives you a discount on this game, and is in itself a pretty good horde survival game), there seem to be many more classes coming, with each class having its unique abillity and weapons(assault can take the high ground with the jetpack, for instance, allowing alternate routes)
-the game seems to take a more casual approach(atleast for now), with the lack of resource management and running back and forth to shops. this does mean that if you drop-in to a lobby in advanced points of the game you wouldnt hinder your team or become a charity case
-much more fast paced movement with the added blink abillity, and new interactions by enemies in the form of fatalities and grapples(which would remind you of dogs from call of duty, except less dramatic because of the isometric)
-the skill tree is not too confusing and simple, albeit a little lacking at this point


the bad:
-atm the game is a little jittery and stutterish. its not at the level where itll ruin your game, but if youre a FPS(frames per second) junkie, or a bit more sensitive to jittery pictures, it may annoy you. nothing you cant ignore if you choose to enjoy the game
-the isometric view does take some getting used to, and somewhat takes away from the difficulty of this genre
-the lack of resource management and shops takes away from the normally hectic purchasing and gear-upgrading that add spice and take away from the redundency of this genre

things that arent good nor bad(atleast in my back)
-there isnt a huge variation of maps at the moment, however its not a big problem as they can still be enjoyed if the game is played casually rather than hardcore grinding
-there is only one game mode at this point(given the game has only just gone up with early access that is to be expected), but it is pretty well made and given this game's *ancestor*'s variety of modes and how well they were made, im very much looking forward to the things to come.

TL;DR : interesting game, if you dont mind the isometric view it can be very enjoyable despite the slightly jittery graphics, although kind of lacking in depth at the moment. i recommend it at this point as im both enjoying my time and expecting something even better to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

26.04.2016 I'm done with this game. It took 2 missions to decide why so:
1. The Early Access phase is an Open Beta or even Open Alpha. It's unfinished, not tested from player-like enviroments, not polished and most of all lacks a reason to be played. There's ntohing in here but a grindfest of few types of missions on few maps.
2. I had troubles with launching it - sometimes it takes forever, sometimes 3 minutes.
3. There is no console.
4. Dedicated servers (few) host all the sessions the players make and they are laggy. Latency varies from 70 to 200 on the same continent.
5. The server browser is 1.6/Source engine-like but lacks the filters.
6. Classes aren't equally useful nor precisely optimised - Support's shotgun provides much more kills than Marksman's rifle, which is even worse than marksman's pistol.
7. Monsters don't react to bullets at all. At 0.1% HP they behave exactly the same way as if they just respawned.

Maybe that's why it's cheap.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's times like this that I really wish I could give a neutral reccomendation. This one is kind of tricky. The game is built with a controller in mind, to the extent that I feel like this is probably something that's on console and ported over with little changes. For what it is, you might get some enjoyment out of it, and I'm rather happy I got to try it before I spent any money on it. (Though for a dollar, you can do far worse on Steam) The problem I suppose, is that the game is still in the early access stages. I feel like it's going to either improve, or stay in the limbo of being early access forever (thankfully it seems the former), but unfortunately my tastes are soured with the title and I see no real reason to come back to it. I would only recommend it to players using the Xbox controller, in particular, since it is optimized for that. Which turns out to be the detrimental downside of being a keyboard purist. This is why I am giving a thumbs down, unfortunately, since it just doesn't do it for me personally.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a co-op twin stick shooter/3PS (you can switch camera angles) that mostly resembles your typical zombie shooter in gameplay, but has the honor of hogging 4 times more resources while having 4 times less things to shoot at. Also, replace zombies with dinosaurs and the protagonists with Gears of War characters piloting Warframes, and tack on some arbitrary RPG elements for good measure. I blame Epic Games.

Seriously though, if you're gonna have adjustable graphics settings, try to make them in a way that the game doesn't become completely unplayable if you turn them all the way down. I literally didn't notice what I was getting attacked by when the first wave of dinosaurs came because they looked like part of the scenery. Had to opt for running the game at 15 FPS to compensate. Hell, my laptop can run L4D2 perfectly, but Unreal Engine 4 put a stop to that real quick.

If you want a good twin stick shooter with slick controls and fast gameplay, go play Assault Android Cactus instead. If you want to shoot at things running at you quickly with friends without having to buy a $2000+ computer, play Left 4 Dead 2.

Not even worth the $2 from the sale. I'd ask for a refund if it were over $5, but I can't be ♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Current Opinion - Strongly do not recommend.

Pros:

Low price / free play time, gives the impression the developers are trying to get traction.


Cons:

Long loading times, seemingly random in nature.  You'll start the game one time and it will come up fairly quickly.  Other times, go watch some TV while you wait.  Same thing goes for going online.

When browsing for a game to join, there are no options to filter games or to sort the list by any of the server properties (i.e. difficulty, ping, map, etc)
Also, while not a major issue, there is no keyboard support while trying to create a character in offline mode.

I only managed to join a friend's game once and it must have been luck.  I repeatedly tried to connect up with my friend and the game refused to allow me to.

I can't recommend this game at all at this point.  They continue to focus on content when the framework is severely broken.  Don't ask me my opinions of the game" part the program when you haven't even bothered to ensure I get there."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well... Honestly, is better if you stick to the original Orion: Prelude.

I really wanted to like this game, and I understand is a beta that is being updated but still...

I am having a bit of trouble with the graphics, I had to reduce the quality overall to avoid frame lag, but that is not the main issue. Compared to the original its still lacking a lot and it went from being a FPS  action packed dinosaur hunt to trying to be a action shooter with top perspective like isometric shooters work (or you can switch to FPS, but you wont do that mostly because Aiming is easier on the top view)

There is no vehicles yet, there is more classes and a crafting system to keep things more interesting... but overall it felt a lot more boring that the original, and it plays more cluncky too. I cannot really recommend it until some really major fixes and updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Great Take on the Twin-Stick Genre

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mii_JjahBqc

Pros:
- Love the Blink Mechanic
- Good Execution.
- Good Lookin'
- Can use steam friends lists for MP

Cons:
- Shallow in terms of content (this something the devs are already working on though)
- Skill Progression Tree Needs some work

This is one of those titles that is way more fun with friends. The single player game is ok but the Multiplayer is where the party is at. In my video, I played with three friends and it was an absolute blast.

I think something that would really take this game to the next level is if there was a co-op campaign that gave the game some purpose with friends, an objective of sorts that focuses your efforts as a team on a certain goal. That plus some tweaks to the skill tree would really turn this into a top notch game.

Look forward to seeing what the future holds for Guardians of Orion. It should be good.
